reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though it's not finished I believe this game blows Game Dev Tycoon out of the water. The only thing GDT has on MGT is being able to build and distribute consoles, which could possibly be added in the future. (I'm not going to compare this game to Software Inc, because it's more about software in general and doesn't go into too much depth(yet) with game development like this and others in the genre).

Features

-Build each room within your building, giving you more control over your company (you can have 100's of employees if you want, it gets a little hard to manage in it's current state, but hopefully that will be fleshed out more)

-Employees skills raise by developing/working (Game Dev has this as a mod, but I feel it works better in this game) also the skills make more sense (GameDesign, Programming, Graphics, Music & Sound, Office Work, Speed, Work Will).

-Employee needs (Bathroom, heating/cooling, and furnishings)

-Research new genres, topics, engine features, game sizes (B - AAA), and game improvements.

-Has WAY more Genre and game topics than GDT, and there is no game genre/topic matching (which never made sense to me, there's no such thing as a bad genre/topic match in the real world, only bad games).

-Release updates/patches for your games after release. (In the beginning you won't be able to fix bugs during development, but you can after release by either patching the game, which will remove a lot of bugs. You can update the game and choose to remove some bugs while also improving the game, which will improve sales as well).

-Eventually you can have seperate rooms to improve your game:
~Game Design (Remove bugs during development and improve gameplay, also where you make game reports)
~Music Studio (obviously improves music/sound)
~Graphic Studio (dem textures)
~Motion Capturing (recently added, I'm not to sure on the specifics, but I believe it improves graphics/gameplay)

-Sell developed game engines and make money off games made with them (you can select the initial price of the engine and the % you receive from sales)

-Customer support room to keep your fans happy once you reach a certain amount. Can also run campaigns to increase fan base

-Publish your game through other companies (they will produce and distribute your game, and occasionally market it).

-Publish your own games! (To do this you need a production room and a storeroom. You can actually choose how many copies of a game you want to make, including the price and things like a t-shirt, game manual etc. You can also re-release older games and eventually release game packages)

-Marketing!

-Build a Server room and release your own MMOs! (Yes Game Dev Tycoon has MMOs too, but it works so much better in this game) You actually choose the Subscription price of your game and have to have enough servers to support your subscribers. Unlike other games, once your MMO stops selling copies it stays on the market, and you can release expansion packs. Expansion packs will act as seperate games (in terms of sales and marketing), but it will also make your base MMO start selling again. There is also a F2P option that is not usable at the moment, so hopefully the way MMO's work in general will be improved.

-Licenses for movies, books, or other games that you can buy. I honestly don't even use this feature as it's not necessary and there's always another game already released under every license anyway so I don't really see the point.

Possible negatives

-(This one really isn't a big deal, but it annoys me). I'm not sure if the Dev is foreign, but the FPS genre is called Ego-Shooter. Never heard this term before and I don't like it at all, I could see Ego-shooter" being used for more arcadey style games like Doom
recommended: and maybe even COD to an extent
hoursPlayed: but it's not a term used in the U.S.\n\n-Managing huge teams can be annoying if you want to make sure you have the best people for each room. There is an auto-assign feature
voteText: but I'm not sure how it decides to assign employees.\n\n-As I stated before
helpfulPercent: you can't create consoles like in GDT
votesHelpful: but hopefully it will be added.\n\n-The aspects of controling the way your game turns out (other than the skills of your employees) have specific settings for each genre that are considered "correct"
votesTotal: but in my opinion GDT's sliders don't work much better.\n\n-No real End game as of yet
votesFunny: and no New game+ like GDT has.\n\n-Each genre has pictures for your game that depend on the level of technology applied used
commentsCount: but don't differ between topics. Ex. if you make a Fantasy Rpg and a Knight Rpg on the same engine
column16: the pictures will be the exact same. Granted no other game in this genre has this from what I've seen.\n\nIf you enjoyed GDT then buy this game
column17: it's way better IMO. I believe this game is worth the price even if it's not finished."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction            	Mad Games Tycoon is a really cool simulator that allows you to form your own game studio and rise through the ranks, from your garage to huge mega million dollar company. You can’t deny that Mad Games Tycoon does not seem a bit similar to Game Dev Tycoon (I guess a lot), but this is not a bad thing. I personally loved Game Dev Tycoon and Mad Games Tycoon deserves love in its own light. The one thing that really sets Mad Games Tycoon apart from Game Dev Tycoon is the fact that it allows so much more customization.(Office Upgrades, Storefronts, Paintings, Plants, different desks, and bookshelves One of the huge draws that Game Dev Tycoon had for me was all of the references to real life game companies and devices; Mad Games Tycoon only expands on this and creates even more amazing references and jokes. (Cupcom, EA, Pony, L ★, and tons more)
Pros
Tons of real life references
Typical/Amazing gameplay
Ton of customization
Great amount of graphic options
Plenty of upgrades and gameplay elements


Cons
Slow paced
Music gets a bit annoying (This may just be me)
Not as simplistic as Game Dev Tycoon

Conclusion
Mad Games Tycoon is tons of fun and just builds of the Game Dev Tycoon formula. If you had fun or are looking for something more complicated game dev sim, Mad Games Tycoon is exactly what you should look at.  It add tons of customization and more in depth game elements. Mad Games Tycoon is a must have for anyone who enjoyed Game Dev Tycoon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon is a game with an identity crisis. It's not sure whether it wants to be an economic simulator for the games market, or a game studio micro-management simulator, and because of that it fails pretty poorly at both. A lot of the reviews laud the game for doing more than Game Dev Tycoon, but Game Dev Tycoon's simplicity is part of why the game is attractive.

The micro-management in MGT is quite tedious at times. When you create a game, you have to select all the priorities, focuses etc. This part is fine. You then have to click on your graphics department and improve the graphics, then click on the audio department and improve the audio, then click on the QA department and improve the gameplay, then click on the motion capture studio and improve the filming & animation. Six times for each of these departments. Similarly, you'll need to micro-manage your production department.

The marketing department can auto-repeat its campaigns, but I'd like to see this expanded into a queue system, where you can give a department jobs and have each job executed when the last finishes. I'd also like to see the ability to link up the QA, graphics & audio departments with a specific development department, so that when I start making a game, those departments automatically queue the improvements I've researched (or at least, so that when I add things to my queue, they're automatically done on the right game).

The development cycle is also very inaccurate. My team of 16 developers (plus 4 QAs, 4 graphics, 4 audio, 4 motion capture) could barely put out an MMO *expansion* every 3 years. Treyarch is a similar-sized studio, and they can put out a full AAA title every 2 years.

Game Dev Tycoon has a 'hype' system which allows me to predict my game's sales. In MGT, I can run a media campaign but I can't have any idea how much it's influenced sales, how many people it's reached etc. It would be great to see more media interactions like interviews, followup articles when my games reach landmark sales or news about my competitors' games.

This brings me onto the other side of the coin, the market simulation. It feels like MGT is trying to simulate a market, this is something I really wanted in Game Dev Tycoon, but it's a very poor simulation.

The competition never seem to decline. They grow until they are valued at $200 million, and then grow no more. A market simulation should correctly simulate their studios in the same way it simulates mine, with the games produced, their scores and their marketing determining which companies thrive and which die and/or are bought. Similarly, I've not seen any of the console manufacturers die. Atari, Sega, Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony are all active in 2050 in my game, all sitting between 8 and 20% market share.

If you're going to simulate this, you'd also need a better media engine to display the information to the player. My competition are buying each other? The RPG market is saturated right now because 5 AAA RPGs were announced at E3 this year? Right now it feels like the competition only exist to be bought and to offer me terrible games to publish. Similarly, the studios I buy, even after being upgraded to 5 stars, rarely give me a game with higher than a 70% score. These studios were winning Game of the Year before I bought them.

Companies should be created (it wouldn't be hard to create random company names) on a regular basis, most would go out of business after one game, but some would go on to be a success. Companies should buy each other. Publishers should buy developers. 'Franchises' should exist, which have fans (separate from company fans) and are transferred when you buy their owners.

Minor bones to pick:
- Random game titles destroy immersion, 'Rabbit Quest' the sports simulation and 'Ice Hockey Manager' the ego shooter? Please create lists of topic/genre specific terms and a better algorithm to create the names.
- Engines are ridiculous. I managed to get from 1980 to 1995 without releasing a game. I just researched, created engines and sold them for $0 + 40% of profit. I made an absolute killing and got to my 3rd office this way.
- The game is too easy. By the end I could buy all the devs for pocket change, and none of them grew to my size/scale.
- No Linux/Mac support in 2015.
- Performance was poor even on modern (i7, 8GB RAM, Intel HD4000) hardware.
- The Marketing menu doesn't have a confirm button. ALL of the other menus do. This has caused me to waste $ on the wrong campaigns multiple times.
- Staff item requirements are ridiculous. I had to buy a cheap refridgerator for my staff room even though I already had the expensive one, had to buy an orange chair in an office where everything was blue, etc.

The game is not without its positives, you really do get a lot of choice, and a lot of control over the focus and design of your studio. You get to know your staff, you can train your teams; you can find a publisher, self-publish or even publish other studios' games. The game has charm and can be enjoyable at times. It's just that the lack of difficulty and a deeper market simulation overshadows the positives.

MGT has a lot of ambition, but really isn't well-tuned in any of it. It is in early access, and if the developers can tighten the scope a little and fix the balance issues, it shows promise to become the forerunner in this emerging niche. Until the developers make the changes I've mentioned, though, I wouldn't recommend anyone spend their money on this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon is a pretty awesome game developer management sim. It's one of the few early access games I've bought, but I'm irrationally obsessed with Game Dev sims like Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story. Eggcode's take on game dev management adds much needed customization options and depth to the experience by allowing you to build rooms and assign employees to specific rooms to perform specific tasks.

Before I get to the bad, I would like to say up front that I freaking love this game. I've had tons of fun and I think it's absolutely worth the purchase if you enjoy tycoon games or want another take on the Game Dev Tycoon style of management sims. The team at Eggcode is a standout example of how to do early access right and deserves recognition for their constant bug fixes and content patches that range from adding new rooms and employees to improving the UI.

That's also part of the frustration of this game. I'm sure that this was a gameplay choice, but having to build special rooms for certain tasks gets annoying. For example, the games core development all happens in one room. Bug fixes have to take place in a seperate room for QA. If it takes the QA team longer to squash the bugs than it takes for the core team to finish development on the game, the development room is rendered useless until you choose to launch the game. Not to mention, the development team can't help fix bugs unless they're dragged away from development and pushed into the QA room. I get that the music studio, art offices and motion capture rooms should be standalone, but why can't the core staff improve level design?

That is my biggest issue. Everything else is a minor problem. I don't like how many clicks it takes to assign tasks to almost every room except for the development rooms. The UI isn't that great. The art isn't terribly nice to look at and I wish there were more (or custom) logos to choose from. But the art didn't effect my enjoyment.

Like I mentioned above, I love this game. It's fun and I've lost afternoons to this game. I can't wait to see how Eggcode continues to improve this already enjoyable game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Disclaimer: This is a long review! Sorry.***

Allow me to preface by saying that I own both the Kairosoft original 'Game Dev Story' on my phone as well as the similar release Game Dev Tycoon here on steam. Huge fan of both, but there was always something missing in a way. I feel like this game takes the things that I liked about both of those games(time/micro management), removes the things that I didn't like(RNG), and adds a few new things to keep me engaged(building)! I spent all day playing this yesterday without even realizing it.

How do they compare? Here is my breakdown so far:

Game Dev Story/Tycoon- You reasearch technology and genres while doing contracts in between for extra cash so that you can eventually release big titles, gain fans, and maybe even take over the world? The not so fun thing about these games was that if you got lucky and managed an amazing score on a certain game, future releases would be forever held to that standard which in turn made it very tedious to try and stay afloat while releasing a quality product that your fans would like. Half of the time the score would seem a bit random even if you did all the right things like combining the right genres and putting your strongest team to work on the more dificult parts. It would get frustrating when you would lose power or your machines would break down, ruining all progress on any of the titles you work on. This isn't so bad at first, but it happens more as the game goes on which effectively makes the time and care you put into making a good game title pointless. You also had to grind out 'Research Points' to be able to learn about anything which took valuable time away from making money among other things. In short, while fun at first, but was hurt by seemingly RNG mechanics and too much micro management which I never thought possible.

Mad Games Tycoon- Still research everything from technology to genres but it only requires money. You can actually design your game company with special rooms just for your developers, researchers, marketers, customer service reps, etc. You can even build a warehouse/production area so you can publish all your games in house and watch them fill the shelves! It made it really easy for me to keep track of who does what and making sure they were on task. You don't have to worry about a previous game's high score effecting future releases with unrealistically imposed standards. You don't lose power or progress and your employee stats are much clearer and easier to gain. You don't have to grind research or any other kind of currency besides just money which allows me to spend my time doing other things to help my company thrive. Training your employees is much less costly and everything from their stats to the game creation seems to be a lot more streamlined. I also love that you can change where any of your employees are working with a simple click and drag.

As far as early access titles go, this product is pretty polished! My only gripes are that once your company starts to get REALLY big the game starts to struggle with the load. I had the big 2 room office which is the largest one you can get and while most things were still running smoothly, the hiring window was really laggy. I also wish there was a way to hit pause on the game time while a dialog box is open notifying me of something so I don't lose time in between tasks.

Things to keep in mind:

This game, like its predecessors, can be very unforgiving at first til you learn how everything works. Expect to restart your game a few times within the first hour of playing as you get the hang of it.

Don't be afraid to exlpore and make mistakes. Try new things! When in doubt, save first! You can reload if things go badly.

You have toggles on the bottom of your screen in case you keep accidentally picking up furniture when trying to click an employee.

Keep an eye out for a sad face icon on the lower left hand side of your screen. That is your employees trying to tell you they need something to thrive. It's usually shelves or fire extinguishers so fix it. Otherwise they work at half their normal speed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. Think Game Dev Tycoon, just you can also be a publisher, more topics, far more indepth, with customizable buildings, a plethora of different room types each with their own specific role in the production/develop of video games, items to customize your Game Company, unlimited time span to play in, and best of all, ludicrously addicting gameplay. And it's only version 0.15! Yes, I know, I sound like a total fanboy... but Game Dev Tycoon left me wanting/craving a Game Development Company Management Simulation that had real depth, that could expand upon the already simplistic yet addicting gameplay with a tad more strategy. Well, this game is it. Absolutely cannot wait to see the finished product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since many of you will probably compare this to Game Dev Tycoon, I suppose it would be a good idea to base this review off of that.

For starters, Mad Games has much deeper strategy that what is in Game Dev Tycoon. You also have competing game companies that you have to deal with if you want the sacred GOTY Award. Or if you'd prefer to be aggressive, you can just buy out all your competition.

As far as comparisons go, they both focus around creating vidya games as well as the gaming empire that surrounds them. Your lil people level up the more they do things, and bankruptcy is a huge threat.

Or to put it simply, Mad Games Tycoon is an excellent compliment to Game Dev Tycoon, and they're both good on their own.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be honest: Mad Games Tycoon was more fun then i expected. In my opinion it delivers enough to be worth buying at this stage of development. Be aware though, it's much different from Game Dev Tycoon. Thats either a pro or a con, depending on the way you look at it. I think its a pro and both games are fun in their own way. One isn't better then the other, they're different and can both be lots of fun.

If i would compare Game Dev Tycoon with Mad Games Tycoon i would say GDT has more focus on the game development and less on business simulation, where as MGT is much more of business simulation tycoon. For example: in MGT you spend relativly more time on upgrading your building, producing games in your factory and managing your staff. And creating a good game itself isn't much of a challange in MGT, compared to GDT.

Pro's:
- enough content to meet the expectations at this stage of development
- lots of charts and stats to play with
- gameplay looks promising, with the more content and challanges it can be a pretty nice game
- actual business simulation elements in it, havn't seen that for a while in a game!
- lots of fun possibilities, like your own game factory

Neutral:
- okay graphics and sound, nothing special
- could use some customization options for the charts

Con's:
- controls are a bit sloppy, but can be changed pretty easy i assume
- creating games isn't much of a challange, it does'nt have to copy GDT but it could be made a bit more challanging
- at the point where you run a big business, it gets a bit hard to keep oversight... this could use some work

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not my first early access purchase. To be honest, of all the titles I own (early acces I mean) I only regret a single purchase. And that's because the title in question went from alpa then to beta and then to full release in a single update. But that's not relevant here so that's the last I'm going to say about that. My point I was trying to make is that early access is ALWAYS a risk.

You know what you are buying in advance and if the game doesn't pan out... Well then that's tough luck.

It is for that reason that early access titles in general are hard to review or to be more precise, it's hard to give a good review about it because the damn thing isn't finished yet.

But at the same time... Is it an excuse? For example, there are many things that could be considered a 'negative' about this title. The majority of the tooltips are missing. Adding those would surely not take all that long right? But on the other hand, that is not something that could be considered a priority.

Completing the tool tips would in my opinion be something you could correct when you are finishing the game up.  Another 'negative' point about this game is the fact that the first language of the dev is german. It isn't English. So the English is a bit... Weird to say the least at times. Humorous but in that 'what the heck is this supposed to mean' kind of thing that makes you smile if only for a moment.

The third and last negative point I will give as an example is the fact that the graphics are seemingly unfocussed and will definetly never win any awards. But that was never in question. I mean, a game like this doesn't NEED state of the art graphics. What would be the point?

Those negative points aside there is also a lot of fun to be had. You can try (and fail in my case) to try and remain a single man developer in an effort to simulate an indy company. Or you can decide for yourself that you're not going to hire more then say five people and that each has to be highly specialized, that you're never going to produce your own games and various other limits. Of course these aren't in game and rely solely on what you decide for yourself.

It took me a while to figure out what would get me a good game. My first games were all beneath fifty. Heck, I was lucky if I got one over thirty five. Then I managed to publish a hit (over eigthy points if I remember right) and the millions start rolling in.

Of course then I got over confident and before I knew it, my millions had gone to 'only' a few thousand in cash.

There are many people who ask this question: how does this game relate to game dev tycoon?

Don't compare them. Each game has its down and upsides in the way they do things. One is finished, the other is not. So again, you can't really compare them YET.

Each game does things differently. Differently enough that it is hard to compare them with each other.

So here is my conclussion.

The dev can certainly use some improvement when it comes to the english l language. After all, and especially if you publish on steam, where the majority of the language is English, knowing and mastering the English language is a must.

Should you buy the game? I myself don't regret buying it and I think that neither will the buyer. If you are unsure then watch some gameplay or let's play video's on youtube. It is what I did myself and if you still aren't convinced then just wait until it gets a sale again.

Kingdark

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the title, Mad Games Tycoon has no correlation to the other Mad game, Tv Tycoon, despite both games sharing a very eerily similar title. The devs deny it but can't help question the likeness. Regardless, Mad Games Tycoon has more in common with Game Dev Tycoon, except that MGT is more indepth and has a lot more too it.

Already as an early access title, its got enough features to keep you entertained. Where as Game Dev Tycoon is more of a mobile type of game, and rather simple in design, Mad is designed to be more PC worthy in that it has a lot more features such as running your own production machines, storage and servers for online games that you have to setup. You also have to setup a support team for technical support, and keep your dev team happy and productive with amenities dotted abuot the office. Although I've yet to see any direct consequences of NOT having stuff around to keep your employee morale up, it may become more prominent later on.

There's also the fact that you can essentially build your own office and place things where you need them. Mad Games Tycoon definitely reminds me of an old PC game called 'Startup' that had a lot of these features, but in the end was a very poor implementation. MGT seems to have gotten it right, so far at least.

Their are a few shortfalls however that the game lacks that I hope the devs work on in the future, this including staff categories and perhaps a more immersive background experience, perhaps a road and some animated cars/people walking by including all the noise that comes with that?

I'm also not sure if modding features are ever going to be supported, but hopefully they will.


Regardless, if you liked Game Dev Tycoon, or even, if you didn't like it and thought it was too simple, then I can recommend this as so far its a great title, and it looks to improve even more in the near future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since I completed Game Dev Tycoon in a few entertaining evenings I have longed for something more.  I waited with much eagerness for some kind of update or sequel but sadly none was forthcoming.  Well thankfully this game came along and I really couldn't be happier.  My review will compare it to Game Dev Tycoon.

PROS:

Game is slower - it really allows for you to get stuck in and enjoy all the little components that involve running your company.  Also allows for you to keep up with the market instead of being one step behind all the time.

More to develop - Not only can you develop games but you can also develop game engines (which is a great way to make some money) this is a lovely touch.  There is also more to develop in terms of what you want in your game.  Plus when you come to produce your own game you have some freedom to decide what to include in the box and how much you want to sell it for.  There are also many more genre's and topics

Buildings - it's refreshing to be able to build and equip your own offices.  Much more freedom to decide how much you want to spend/how many people you want working on something.

Staff Training - much easier, much quicker and much more effective

CONS:

Can get annoying when people won't work for you because you don't have a certain fridge or seat.  In some cases I have had the luxury version but people won't work for me because I didn't have the cheaper version.

UI can get a little annoying.  I can't think of how to describe it but the expanding boxes type of thing becomes monotonous and you have to go through a few boxes sometimes to get what you want.  Be good to be able to pick multiple things too, especially when selecting platforms.  The screen can become a little cluttered also.  Be nice if the full screen would work but I can't seem to get it to do so.

No ability to develop your own console (at least not that I have found).

No tutorial although it is easy enough to figure out.

OVERALL:

This is a really good game and I'm sure it will continue to improve.  It is far better than Game Dev Tycoon and provides an enjoyable gaming experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love Game Dev sims. Game Dev Story was one of those games that managed to burn away many hours of my life. It still is one of my favourite games on my iPhone. And for a long time, it was also pretty much the only game of its kind. Thankfully, Game Dev Tycoon came out in 2012. While it managed to be similar to the aforementioned game, it was also a bit more complex and supported mods. I played it a lot back in the day, but it never became an evergreen for me. Thankfully, Mad Games Tycoon has been in Early Access for some time now and I think it's the right moment to write this little review of it.

Mad Games Tycoon takes a similar, but more complex approach to the topic at hand: You start off in a garage, alone, with your new company and you immediately get to build rooms, Theme Hospital-style. You even get to buy furniture, which has some impact on hiring new employees for your young studio. More talented people only pop up, if your company has enough stars, which in turn are determined by the quality of furniture you have in your office. At the beginning, you won't have a lot of stars, since you need most of your money in order to finance your first games. While they are cheap to produce at the beginning, you have running costs, like the salaries of your employees and of course the upkeep of your studio.

Producing games is relatively simple at first. You define the name, genre and focus of your game. Each genre has a different focus, so you'll have to experiment and invest in a quality assurance department in order to find out what's the perfect mix. The closer you get, the higher the critics score your game and the better your game will sell. Later on, you can even combine some genres, but some combinations work better than others. You also take care of updating your games, which can have a positive impact on sales.

While this certainly sounds easy enough, there are additional things you can take care of. You can decide to develop your engines yourself, which has the added benefit that you can sell said engine to other game producers and get a fraction of the money they make with games that use your engine. This means you'll also have to invest time and money into research. Buying a licence for a third party engine is an option too, of course, but you'll be loosing a portion of your profits.

When your games start getting bigger, you'll need to invest in a quality assurance department and dedicated graphics, music and motion capture studios, in order to improve those areas of your games. This also means you'll need bigger offices quick and this is where one of my biggest problems with this game can be found: When you get a new office, you'll need to build all your departments from scratch and reassign your entire workforce. Now, this is manageable the first time around, but it gets tough quickly. In one of my games, I had a workforce of over 100 people and it was impossible to assign them properly in a timely manner. Sure, you have the possibility to arrange them by five different attributes, but that is not enough. The game lacks a filter for unassigned workforce, which makes life harder than it needs to be. Maybe this will be added at some point later in the development.

The latest addition to the game is console development. While it doesn't look like it's completely integrated yet, it is pretty awesome to research and develop your own console and push it on the market to let it go up against the NES. You can set the price for your console and developing for it is pretty cheap. Unfortunately, right now I haven't managed to develop an exclusive title that turned a profit...

While the gameplay is fun and the systems are comprehensive, the presentation still leaves a bit to be desired. Graphics are simple, yet functional and the music is ok for the first couple of hours but soon starts to get on your nerves. Some soundeffects are overused, especially the telephone, which thankfully can be switched off separately. Performance takes a notable hit too when there are more than 100 people working in your studio.

While these are some important complaints I have about the game, I'm also certain that at least some of those things will improve over time. But right now, Mad Games Tycoon is the Game Dev-Sim to go! It's more complex and more satisfying in almost every way compared to similar games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was hesitant at first to buy Mad Games Tycoon until it was 50% off, but after 10+ hours of the game, I am becoming increasingly happy with the game and the community are very nice people. You, the reader already knows that you are your own game development company, but more of a Sims effect is placed in the game, because you the owner are to create different rooms including development, research, etc. and place objects in there including desks, etc. The more starred things you purchase, the better employees you hire and the further efficient your staff and you are.

Making the games is a fun process. It varies each game you produce, but it can get annoying considering it gives you hints as to whether which side you should make your game. For example, do you choose more of a focus on graphics over gameplay or vice versa, and after creating a game for that genre, it would give a suggestion to go to say, the graphics side of things. It can get very easy and with the limited amounts of genres and topics, it is easy to reproduce the same type of game with the same focus under a different name and get a high rating.

The game however, is in early access still (I'd say mid Alpha as there aren't all features implemented yet) and for right now, the basics are there, they just have to be developed more. For example, I'd love to have more of a intertwine between the games you make and how that affects the NPC world, does it affect the sales of your competitors, or vice versa. The similarities are there with Game Dev Tycoon, but I think both are distinct. They follow the same basic guideline of making games, but both do so in a different way and I personally think Mad Games Tycoon is much more in-depth so far than Game Dev Tycoon, especially in the Alpha stage.

The later part of the game (Past 2010) is not fully developed yet. The NPC companies work still the same, but I find an unbalanced effect happening. Playing in easy, by 2010, I have released about 10 games with three hitting first on the all-time charts, by 3x what the NPC game was. My three would final sell at 13+ million copies while the highest NPC one would be 4.5 million. Another example is, less features pop-up following 2010 and I have noticed by 2020, the game has stopped releasing consles, features to develop, but NPCs still release there games. To expand on this though, I'd think that everything hasn't been implemented purely because with all features so far in the game being researched, there is 41 or 42 features (and with the improvements in features like parallex scrolling compared to basic scrolling) the usable count in a AAA game (mind you, AAA games allow 50 features max) is about 33. Thats my own real flaws as it can become increasingly easy late game, but then again, I'm playing on easy and haven't really tested the higher difficulties as I had did a full playthrough of normal, but that was prior to a patch recently while buffed the difficulties of all levels.

At the moment, I'd say buy the game. I have had two full run throughs in about 10 hours, with the game setting on easy and me fast forwarding everything. It isn't a full finished product yet and the updates are regular (actually the updates coming every week or week and a half and if a hotfix is needed, a hot fix comes about 2-3 days following), though in saying that it is solid enough to have run throughs without being bored. The use of NPCs which are a major hit, different variaties of producing the game including motion capture studio, etc. and the building effect make this game a solid outing thus far, more in-depth than GDT personally, and with a suggestion thread that the developer usually follows apart from his own wishlist (though the thread will stop recieving suggestions on April 30th), the game will improve along the way and become better.

Currently, a rating is not needed but I recommend buying it at your own risk. For the average player that plays this, you can easily get 15 hours out of the game minimum, and I haven't done that yet because I had only bought it a week ago, though I have only had playthroughs mainly on easy, and will go to the next difficulty soon. If you are still hesitant following my review, if you do like these types of game, wait until it goes on sale because if it does on the summer sale, it will most likely be 50% off and will be $7.50, though sale or no sale, I think it is a must buy for the management fan.

----

Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is one of my favourites. It combines aspects from games like GamersGoMakers and Game Dev Tycoon to make an amazing Game Studio Simulation. An all round super-fun game.

Pros:
-Amazing office building and customization
-Brilliant Character customization
-Unlocks system is a very good concept
-Much more historical than other games, the vanilla game features a lot more platforms to develop for
-Any Game Dev Tycoon player or GamersGoMakers player will know the feeling when you make a game engine then 2 days later there are new things to research which make your games better, well in Mad Games Tycoon you can improve old engines by adding stuff to them after release. You can also sell your engines for other companies to buy!
-Adding in things to improve your games like Copy Protection, Buying engines and rooms like the Graphic and Music studio, Customer Support and Quality Assurance are great!
-Being able to self-publish games is super cool, being able to choose what goes into the box when you sell your game is also just fantastic.
-Being able to make patches, bug fixes, MMO Addons and Langauge packs for released games is awesome
-Many other features which generally make the game amazing...

Cons:
-AI pathfinding when you put them in a room can be messed up
-Game isn't very challenging after a while
-Could do with a workshop so the Community can create mods (more topics, genres, consoles etc.)


9.5/10 And its still in Development! Hopefully if they can fix some of the issues and add a few more features then the game will be a 10/10. In my opinion better than Game Dev Tycoon and GamersGoMakers, would reccomend highly.

I had wish listed this game, and decided to give it a try when it went on sale via Steam.

My expectations were fairly low given that Game Dev Tycoon is already out there, and the fact that this is in early access.  That said, I was pleasantly surprised to learn that I had severely underestimated this game.  From a strategic standpoint, as well as various gameplay options, it provides a deeper experience than Game Dev Tycoon (not to continually compare the two, but I'm having a difficult time avoiding that).

The added element of designing how to utilize your blank work spaces was a welcome wrinkle, as compared to other games of this type.

I've purchased and played Game Dev Tycoon, GamersGoMakers, as well as Game Dev Story on mobile.  To me, on balance, Game Dev Tycoon was the best of these games.  Once this version is complete, I believe this will be the go-to game making" game for me.

If you're a fan of Game Dev Tycoon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

|Disclaimer: Game goes on sale regularly, so don't pay full price, if you want to buy it.|

This game is developing slowly, but steadily into the right direction. It's already completely enjoyable to play and feels feature complete for the price tag.

There are a couple of games similar to Game Dev Tycoon out there and this one has become my favourite, because it just keeps throwing features, genres, technologies and stuff at you all the time, basically incorporates the entire Game Developing and Console Developing features from GameDevTycoon while improving on it.

If you have played Gamers Go Makers or GameCorp DX you will realize that the genre actually offers a lot of possibilities in regards of adding rooms and facilities. Mad Games is the only game in the field that let's you create big teams doing different things in different rooms with a decent presentation.

In addition you get stuff like MMOs with a Server Room, Sequels for great games and Add-Ons for the MMOs.

The game development itself is pretty much the same in all games. You can use look-up-tables on the net to create the perfect game or stumble your way to perfection with your own table, or memory. With all the Genres and Topics in the game you will probably go crazy making your own table and definitely unable to remember everything that worked with all the sliders.

Mad Games not only takes the hint" feature that Game Dev Tycoon introduced with a patch
date: but it also lets you re-apply the same setup from a previous project. The advantage being
recommended: that you can develop an RPG
hoursPlayed: then a Sports Game and then another RPG
voteText: load the RPG settings and re-adjust from there on out
helpfulPercent: instead of being forced to manually switch everything back from Sports to RPG. And thanks to the "hints" that appear
votesHelpful: the more you develop within a certain topic/genre mix
votesTotal:
the more of those hints you will see and the better your team becomes.


Is it the perfect game? Not by a long shot.

It's way too easy too be a successfull developer and the result is that I have no idea how platforms and genre mixes work.

Your workers don't age and their wages are quite low in comparison to what they start earning for you. This makes the game easier
votesFunny: but on the other hand you don't get the management horror of a Software Inc.
commentsCount: which is nice.\n\nOnce you develope a great ♥♥♥♥♥♥me you are done. It's GG. You could say that this is realistic and you are probably right. Just look at the history of Blizzard. If you are going for money
column16: go for subscribers. You can also release a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sports game every year without learning anything in the process or improving the engine
column17: so that's realistic
column18: but also too simple.\n\nOverall the best reimagination of the original GameDevTycoon concept by Greenheartgames. I'm sure we are going to see another one of those in the future that will surpass Mad Games
column19:
but for now I'm declaring it the best game developing tycoon out there.

I wish there were more games in that style. Especially if they could switch from Game making into a more detailed movie making simulation. A blend of the classic Molyneux' The Movies with the now 2nd Generation Indie Management games would be the best.

For the presence

Im always on the lookout for any kind of decent tycoon game and this kept me interest. I bought it yesterday, played 19 hours straight. This is an early access game I really hope will be polished and completed.

Few things I will add for devs to look into. (suggestions)
1. I would love to be able to expand over multiple floors /buildings not just be confined to the single floor.
2. Object placements need to be finely tuned, I go all OCD when it comes to arranging things exactly how I want them, and atm, its a little annoying.
3. Able to branch out to other things other than just programming games. Web based, Operating systems, Computer systems.
4. The game speeds are way to fast, would prefer the entire game to slow down a bit, as its basically pointless early on to make games for anything other than PC.
5. Be able to follow a created item from start to finish, more involvement in the programming design, packaging, sales etc.
6. At the completion of a game, would like it to automatically slow(option) the game, otherwise you miss a month when its on highest speed setting.
7. Be able to manufacture more than 9,999,999 at a time. At the end game level, its really restricting not being able to produce any amount you please, especially considering its easy to sell 20-25million copies of a game.
8. I'm sure Ill think of other things later. Just woke up. =)
9. Please take this game all the way to conclusion. Not enough good tycoon games in the world.

10. BYE!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, yes...  all you're games are belong to me.

If you've ever dreamed of building a super cool game company, and wanted to watch your dream grow and then suddenly be snuffed by a large bank to whom you owe millions of dollars, and who you can't possibly repay because you're game sales have no staying power, because for some reason, the public doesn't appreciate your killer new RTS about a super cool donkey civilization trying to save the world from the evil rabbit robots, well... you've come to the right place.

It seems my goal is to create as large as company as possible, so I can layoff 30 or 40 employees instead of just 3 or 4 of my closest friends working out of my garage, when the walls finally cave in.

Build rooms, put people in them, make them create games, research techs through the years, train these people so they stay on the leading edge, develop new techs like quality assurance, graphics labs and sound studios.... and build and use them.  Get some marketing types and stick them in a room to sell your games, some phone workers to make you look professional, and eventually some big printers to mint your own games...  that's about the way it goes.

As tycoon games go, it is actually very cool.  The only thing about it I don't like much, but is probably unavoidable, is that when you move your company to a new building you have to completely redesign the entire interior.... but no big deal.

The developer is fast.  New content comes out all the time, and the updates and bug fixes are rapid fire as well.  There are a few bugs still, but nothing that really affects your game play.  Just annoying, little things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To begin I would like to say that this game is in alpha so take everything with a grain of salt as it may change in the future. I like were they are going with this game. Game Dev Tycoon had small problems such as a limited staff to start off with. Also once you make one type of game you cannot make a game of the same type or it would bomb. I feel like that does not represent real life game development at all.

Mad Games Tycoon changes that. It keeps the similar layout that Game Dev Tycoon had and allowed for you to do what you want as many times as you want. Like to make mid evil rpgs make as many as you want. With that being said there are some problems with the game(Its in alpha to be expected).

First MMOs do not make since. You can make your game have a subscription fee yet not have but a small fraction of the game sells have the subscription. Also with the production costs and server costs they make very little to no money.

Also right now it really doesn't have any type of penalty for making a game that makes no since such as some people have said in their reviews. You can make an music RPG/shooter and get game of the year. Of coarse stuff like this will more than likely implemented later down the road. Also if you get into the game some and hire a lot of people money will never be a problem. This is do to the fact that a game can get more than enough points to be game of the year if you have the staff, and make serious money from anything you develop.

I will recommend the game if you have the money and don't care that it is in early development. If that is not the case pass until it releases in the coming months.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is no denying that this game has taken a huge amount of inspiration from Game Dev Tycoon. The game feels similar due to a similar layout, a lot of similar functions, and even the music is oddly reminiscent of Game Dev Tycoon. The thing this game does well though, is that it locates a lot of the flaws in Game Dev Tycoon and fixes them. This could easily have been called Game Dev Tycoon 2 and no one would have doubted it for a second.

I personally love that this game lets you have more than one development team, more than one research team, etc. It increases the pace at which your company grows immensly and it gives you more to do while waiting for a game to finish developing. The production element is also quite interesting, as you can print your own games and determine price, rarity and more. You are also able to buy other gaming companies, and release their games as your own, where you take the majority of the profit. While it's a fun element at first, it can get quite demanding if you own a lot of companies, as they produce a lot of games! If you're like me, you'll even forget to release your own games and instead just rake in 100+ million every year releasing other companies games.

Overall, the game runs extremely well for an early access game. It has a lot of cool features and expands brilliantly on top of an already terrific design by Game Dev Tycoon. It'll be interesting to see what other features they have lined up for the completed version, but so far I love this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Early Access Review-

Well, where to begin with Mad Games Tycoon? Would I recommend it in its current state? Yes. Yes I would.
I bought this game today, I played it non-stop and have now ran out of content after building my one man in his garage into an enormous empire with around $2270m. More content will be added in the future as a few rooms are locked and I assume more techonology advancements and the likes will be added, so fun fun!

Pros:

+Its addicting, seriously.
+The customisation for the rooms is interesting.
+Plenty of choice and competition.
+There is already a fairly large amount of content, even for an EA.
+The graphics are nice and fit in well with the theme.
+The choices when making a game are pretty cool and varied.
+The different stats on your workers allow for some tactical placement early game.
+Updates appear to come quickly and in response to community demand, which is nice for an EA! (Cough, Starforge, Cough)

Cons:

-The music. God damn. I had to mute it after about 20 minutes as I felt an urge creeping upon me to douse my computer in petrol.
-Placement of items is still a little so-so, I've bugged it a few times and had desks stuck in walls and objects placed over the tops of each other. (Just another minor issue with EA)
-The MMORPG's subscribers drop off in drones randomly you are also unable to make expansions at the moment, if I'm wrong correct me. ( I just didn't see a way)
-Once you have money, it is beyond easy regardless of difficulty.
-Needs more level 3 publishers to allow for greater yeild on your prefered games. (Current set-up makes RPG's less than profitable)


Interesting bits!
* The random speech is quite fun actually, with strange little references to other games.
* Some of the current bugs can be funny and are not particually game-breaking. (one of my workers was typing on a plant and cupboard)
*The names - Seriously - They are great little knock offs. I love it!


To sum up, even in its current state it is well worth the purchase and the time. The developers are community-centric and update often with bug fixes and content. There is much more to come so pay up, support the developers and reap those rewards!

Current rating: 7/10

~Liquifiction

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great cheap game! The idea is to build a successful video game development empire.

1. The beginning is a little tough. Game development is expensive, and you rarely make a profit. I recommend concentrating resources on research and development of an engine in the beginning, at least then you can make some money off others.
2. The tutorial is rather brief, and just brushes the surface of things. Basically, how to build a room, hire staff, and develop a game. A lot of the finer aspects need to be figured out after, but it's not that difficult.
3. The sounds I find slightly annoying, so I just mute it.
4. If you plan for expansion you should do well. It's tricky to get that first profitable game, but once you do it seems like things start getting a little easier.

Ultimately for $8 there is plenty of play here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon is a lightweight management game focused on the games industry.

Lightweight in the context that the player is not flooded with analysis sheets left and right or financial reports but instead cuts through to the point - center attention on management and keeping the corner of the eye on the company liquid balance. Effective and fun.

_____________________________________________

[ early access review @ 20 August 2015 ]

The topic chosen is quite appealing and I must comment on the alter-names and logos of all the companies I know by heart given I went through them all during my PC gamer life and those that really made history like Microprose, Ocean and Activision just to say a trio.

The graphic department is competent. It does what it is intended - gives movement, colour and life to a time sheet". There are some issues with colours but nothing that takes away value. My guess is some further work on it.

The sounds are there. Mechanic types and directed mainly to the alerts and to signal the progression of the tasks being performed. Would enjoy some variation and explicity especially on the events like the games conventions and marketing campains.

Mad Games Tycoon mechanics are good and open way to great diversity. We have all the technical departments in place
date: at least the major ones and the liberty to self manage a dynamic shift of responsabilities on the different offices is notable when compared to other tycoons where there are limits. For example I can build mini offices with all the necessary departments and develop several projects at the same time. Other tycoons fail at this. A plus on this mechanic.\n\nThe Marketing and Customer department mechanics need more depth
recommended: after all they ARE one of the most important aspects of the gaming culture :) Also it would be top work if we get the reports for the campaigns.\n\nThe Games Engines part is weak at best. While games can be buggy the engines are flawless. I bet this part will change for the best so we can develop a subsidiary dedicated to engines with their own issues
hoursPlayed: so better branching par with the Production mechanics are needed.\n\nIn the optimization side
voteText: the game can demand a bit from the shared graphics laptops. With a dedicated graphics everything goes very smooth. This being said and from a propective buyer point of view one would expect a average specs laptop with an SSD to run it okay especially with all blows and whistles turned off. It is early access and this can change as well.\n\nTo close it
helpfulPercent:
this will be a entertaining game. Very fun at this stage already even with all the raw mechanics.

If attention is given to the core rules of the game in the upcoming development cycle we might have a lot more to review.

A great Indie project."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never been a fan of early access. Also, I have never written a worthwhile review before. This game changed my mind on both of those.

***How I feel about Early Access and these developers***
My problem with early access, I've seen to many games cost $20+ for a game that is anywhere from 10-40% complete, and that just doesn't seem fair to the consumer. I have also heard when games have been sold cheap for Early Access but then has to be repurchased upon realease. Both of these are reasons that kept me away from Early Access. This team of developers has changed my mind on this. Eggcode has made me happy to finally be a pleased supporter of an Early Access game. They release a sizeable update approximately every week. It shows that they care about their project even though they could take the money and run right now. Also, when I bought this it was clear and upfront that the game was considered 15% whole. This was a great change than what I've seen. With each update it shows that they are listening to the customers and are on top of things like the small details such as March 24th when to numbers would display switched with each other. This didn't need to get tackled so rapidly, but they chose to be on top of even the small details.

***The Game***
This may or may not be the most accurate depiction of the game based upon when you read it because updates are happening approximately weekly. The game had a good bell curve of difficulty. I felt like I was trying to climb and try every angle at the beginning with little success but enough to stay afloat. As you succeed at creating games or doing contract work you can afford to keep employees. They are not extremely dynamic yet, but after about 2 employees they start requiring items such as a couch for sitting
date:
vending machines, (humorously) toilets, arcade games, etc. These employees have monthly salaries which make you have to continue working. The employees cost more as they level up later in the game. You can train your avatar as well as your employees which lead to better games and faster contract work, but cost more as the get better.

Your employees have multiple facets: making games, contract work to make some quick money, marketing to sell more games, customer service to keep your fan base happy, and research.

The games seem to change with time. At the beginning you can make a game that sells enough" to keep you going
recommended: but as the game progresses your one man or woman indie game team won't keep you alive. Later in the game it does take a team to make good games happen fast enough to sell on whatever the current market is.\n\nThere is more to say about this game. I spent 20+ hours making 10+ billion dollars and called it quits at that point with a team of 25 fully trained game developers
hoursPlayed: 8 customer service pros
voteText: and 8 marketing pros. I look forward to "replaying" this game as the updates progress
helpfulPercent: and hopefully I can update this review as time progresses.\n\n?/10 the game isn't finished so this wouldn't be valid. It's an enjoyable game that goes at your pace. Late late game is a breeze
votesHelpful:
but other than that I have no complaints and this game is currently the best Game Tycoon game out there.

Thanks Eggcode for changing my mind about Early Access Games!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has pretty much perfected its genre. It has a depth that no other game development sims have. The skill floor is just low enough to be able to jump in with just a little help from the tutorial, while the skill ceiling is unimaginably high. There are many ways to increase the efficiency of game production, from assigning staff to certain departments, making sure you're fitting the current trend, and even having a reasonable office layout. The different kind of company you can be also beats out any of the game's competition. You don't even have to rely solely on games. You can produce state-of-the-art engines and license them, you can be a games publisher, and you can even be a console producer and just make a first party game every once in a while.

All in all, this game is thoroughly enjoyable and a definite must have for any fan of game dev sims. 9/10 in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon starts off just like GDS and GDT, you start off in a garage and it's a struggle to release a good first game, however once you have had your first good title, the game seems to get too easy, you just get better and very rarely fail, which is a shame as it would add to the realism if you made bad games as well as good ones.

Mad Games Tycoon has all the features you love from GDS and GDT, but expands up on them, not only do you make games, you also build the studio and you can become an exclusively Production compay only company, which is a really good feature, you build a Production facility and a Store House and then you can make money from selling other companies games and with this you can fail if you don't pick the right game to publish.

There is a feature that allows you to buy rights to Movies and Books and then produce a game from that book or movie, they have their popularity and also have their funny parodies of other Movies and Books, which some of them are quite funny and relevant to todays Books and Movies.

The work spaces you get to buy and occupy are pretty big and fairly cheap as well, the only problem is when you get to the final Office, it becomes a little laggy, this is especially noticable in the Hire menu, but this is the only lag that I have spotted so far.

The menus are easy to navigate and simple to use, though they do look like they have been pulled from a mobile game, the scrolling is a little slow though, but this is by no means an issue.

After roughly 6 hours of playing I seem to have done everyhting in the game, it progresses a lot faster than GDT and GDS, which I hope is by design for future features.

You can buy out your competitors which allow you to publish their games if you want or you can let them continue as they are, though they don't seem to make you money unless you publish for them.

Pros:
Easy to learn
A lot to do while waiting
A nice building mechanic
Competitors that actually have a presence
Cons:
Too easy
The progression is a little too fast
Gets a little laggy once you hit the last office
Menus feel like they are from a mobile game
Overall I find Mad Games Tycoon a very enjoyable game, I will be looking forward to what the devs have planned in the future.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor a Game in Alpha to be this good is astounding. The controls are a bit iffy and has a little learning curve but once you get the hang of that things get fun. Now you need to be prepared, this game is not at all like Game Dev Tycoon. Game Dev Tycoon focuses more on developing games to make money. Mad Games tycoon focuses on expanding and creating not just video games, but game engines as well as the layout and size of your building. There are a little things that can be frusterating when you make your first few games but once you get into the swing of things it's easy. In this respect the game is alot more immersive than GDT because you honestly never know what the finished product will be like. This game is great and even though there are a few buggy things (Which is to be expected when a game is in alpha) the dev team is working hard to fix it. 9/10 for the experience alone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is shaping up to overtake Game Dev Tycoon. For an early access game, it is pretty much feature complete. It is much more in-depth, and has some great ideas that add to the game's realistic feel (like developing and selling engines to have a cut from the competitors profits). Unlike GDT, it includes some basic spatial management in the vein of Theme Hospital, meaning that you have to do some floor planning and deal with the furnishing issues. That isn't everyone's cup of tea, but I'm ok with this - if only you couldn't buy the best equipment available straight out from the beginning and had to unlock it instead. Production and marketing are supposed to be just as vital for your success as research and development. Speaking of which, Mad Games Tycoon is always telling what technology you are researching (rather than using the generic '3D graphics level 2') and even showing what the game you are developing is supposed to look like (not without some quirks - I have developed a FPS using the early 90s technologies, but the screenshot was more like Counter Strike).

So far, all of the concepts implemented in Mad Games Tycoon look good, and the only issues are the game balance (for instance, once you have unlocked the engine development, you can switch to it and never bother with developing actual games to stay afloat), the interface that requires some easing into, and the updates that break your savegame compatibility. All of these issues are perfectly normal and excusable for an early access game. I'd like to add that during my 30-odd hours of gameplay I've not had a single crash, which is a no small feat for an EA game either.

TL;DR:

Pros:

+More content and depth than the other games of that genre;
+Frequent and meaningful updates;
+Stability.

Cons:

-Balance issues;
-Some major updates break the savegame compatibility;
-User interface.


Bottom line:

Highly recommended for anyone who is into that genre/topic.

This game has a lot of depth, and is loads of fun. At times, it can seem frustrating: Just keep in mind that starting out isn't always easy. I thought I would be more upset with the save game wipes, but it actually wasn't bad- It wasn't until starting over that I realized all the things that I could improve upon from my previous game. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game Dev Tycoon meets The Sims!
Mad Games Tycoon does not only allow the player to create a Software Company, the player also needs to care for its employees’ needs in order to hire and motivate them to work (pay and perks). Do you want that RPG specialist who is also great at the graphics that your own engine supports? Then you will have to buy a certain “furniture” or an “arcade game” first before he or she even considers to accept your job offer! A Fantastic Idea!

The game also runs really well for an Early Access application. I’ve not encountered a single bug, yet. Sure, there are some features that are not in game but that comes with the territory. The devs also really take into account its customers’ ideas into incorporating them into the game’s updates.

However, one major flaw that I’ve come across thus far is that Save Games from prior game versions do not load properly whenever the game updates. The player loses hours of gameplay and progress that way. Nonetheless, it’s really not a consequence because starting over keeps the game fresh while offering new contents and its own challenges.

A few things I have on my Wishlist are the following:
Be able to quickly sort through applicants by certain genre or feature specialties when hiring new employees
Be able to have an idea of projected sales from Marketing to help with self-production
Random events in gaming industry that cause competition to fail and rise (i.e. random R&D breakthroughs that become players own license, market recessions, bankruptcy, or even new competitions such Indie Devs)
More end game features such as Digital Download Services, Market Investments, Building our own consoles or platforms, to name a few

8 / 10 – Great Early Access game! Greatly recommended and worth checking out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in its current unfinished state, Mad Games Tycoon is a great game! Initially I thought it looked like a Zynga-esque rip-off of Games Dev Tycoon, but I took a gamble on it during a sale and to be honest I find MGT is the better game! There are very many similarities between MGT and GDT but Mad Games feels like the less mobile-version game of the two. It has a watered down, but still enjoyable, Sims-ish building/management component that GDT does not. But the best element about the game in my opinion is the actual game making itself. I found it infinitely more enjoyable and transparent than GDT, where the quality of your games feels like a crap shoot and you are not penalized so harshly for being imaginative and drifting from obvious genres. Instead of the Tech/Design ratio thing GDT has, MGT has a numerical graphics/sound/controls/technology pool which is influenced by the visible stats of your staff, making way easier to understand where you game succeeded/failed. Similarly, any feature extras like 'sprites', 'vibration controller support' etc contribute directly to the game in transparent ways that make sense, such as 'sprites' contributing to the graphics quality of the game, 'vibration' improving the controls, etc.

Also, every update the dev releases (which is about 1 a month or less) has been excellent and not just bug bashes, and he seems very responsive to feature requests on the Steam forums. He has also been very cooperative about making the games files available for modding, allowing us to rename companies and products to their real-life counterparts.

So if you like GDT, I recommend this! I find it like a less mobile, more in-depth and (most importantly) more transparent version of GDT, and even then it is still an early access with features being added to it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not usually one for writing reviews but I felt it necessary in this instance. This is genuinely the best game dev title I have ever played (and I have played the vast majority of them).

Pros:
*It takes a little while to get used to, particularly ways to make money which is a nice challenge, but with well balanced difficulty levels, on a second play through, I found that I had learned from my mistakes and was making huge progress whilst still in the 80s.
*There is so much depth to the game - tons of things to research, manufacture your own (and competitors) games, produce game engines that you can keep to yourself or sell and profit share, choose what to put in the box (merchandise etc), Train staff and much much more...
*I love the fact that the staff in the game will move to the rooms that best fit their skills automatically (you can turn this off) and they will move to other rooms depending on where you need them during the development process.

Cons:
*The odd gramatical or spelling error
*When moving into new premises, you have to build ALL your rooms etc, all over again.
*Other than moving the door or deleting the room entirely, you're unable to amend the footprint of the room.
*Graphics could be a little better

In summary, a superb little game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game about making games sounds like no fun at all?

It its fun, its madly fun, and are some of the reasons why:

You can choose a lot of things to put in your games, form its genre to the people who design it, to the way you can publish it, etc.

You can make your own office and customize it,  you can even customize workers, and yourself.

You can make your office better at whatever you want, making excelent rpg shoters with great sound, or making puzzles with great playability, or even making a publishing, marketing studio.

All of those things make you feel like putting a kind of hearth in your games, in your workers and in your company.

The only thing that doesnt fit at all is the difficulty level, when you hit certain level of time, like in the 2000´s, you can sell almost any game, it doesnt matter if choosed the hard setting,

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this is early access in my opinion it is a solid game as it stands with a decent amount of features and depth already, i like you can select which country to base your company in and choose what your character can specialise in. Those of you who remember the Theme Hospital game will recognise the same room customisation, buying of furniture, plants, vending machines etc. (something else I like) and the ability to grab hold of any lazy employees and plonk back to their work station.

This is a more indepth Game Dev Tycoon so chances are if you enjoyed that game then you will enjoy Mad Games Tycoon, it will take a fair bit of working out how to make decent games and I very much enjoyed doing so. Only thing that really irks me about this game at the moment is that when trying to pick up your employees its very easy to grab a piece of furniture (like the desk they are working on) instead, hopefully its something can that can be addressed in future updates.

Very keen to see what updates follow, definitely worth getting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, it obviously is very much based on that other game dev tycoon game. The title is a bit underwhelming, and I expected a pretty bad rip-off. At first, I thought I was right, as the starting situation, with your company in your basement and a car next door reminded me quite a bit of a certain other game.

However, soon you realize that this game has more features. You can design your office, controlling the size of each room and what is being worked on in that room. You assign dev- or research projects to a room, and the more people work in it, and the more advanced they are, the faster the result is done.

You can even start to produce the games yourself, which requires a manufacturing room with CD presses and a storage room (make sure you get both, they dont need employees in them, but before you have both, production won't start, and you wanna have the game available as soon as it was developed).

Moving to a bigger space requires a bit more work... you sell old office stuff, move into the new space... and it's all empty. So you have to build those walls, decorate and furnish the rooms and assign your workers, which of course still get paid while you build, so it helps to go room by room so you can assign people quickly.

In general, the game has more detail than that other game (Which I enjoyed a lot as well, btw!!), has more options and features which DO make sense, and seems to be shaping up quite nicely. My first play-session lasted for 3 hrs straight with no break, and I am looking forward to continuing. Not sure how much replay-value the game has once you have become the big and rich tycoon, but until then, its a very enjoyable and slightly addictive game.

Still a lot of potential and I'm looking forward seeing this grow over time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All my initial problems are fixed. The game also now has enough content to warrant a buy. I say, go ahead, get it. I also want to add that whenever I suggest something, it gets enough attention so that it is either fixed or implemented as a feature or option. The developer(s) of this game is amazing and the community is also working. I couldn't be happier with my purchase.

Go to the bottom for TL;DR version.

This game has a lot of Theme Hospital inspirations. Like how your staff needs radiators to be productive or how certain staff members can only be hired when you have certain items. The game's atmosphere is nice on its own and it has a lot of topics and genres and features for your development journey.

Now, let's talk about the downsides of this early access. First of all, there isn't much of a tutorial on how things work, the only tutorial you're given is at the start and it's pretty simplistic. After that you have to unlock certain stuff by doing other stuff. Researching a feature to be able to make your own engine for example. However, the buildings that you unlock have no tooltips whatsoever and you can only go for a trial and error approach. They do have tooltip boxes though so they're sure to be explained later on in an update. There are also some minor grammatical errors or typos but nothing too bothersome.

Now, if you have bought the game and you're just starting out, don't invest in the last 3 skills. They are only ever useful for research, marketing and support. Get skills other than music, sound and graphics since those are the first few employees available to you and you can just get one if you need.

TL;DR version: This game is like Theme Hospital meets Game Dev Tycoon. It is in Early Access but it doesn't have any bugs that I can see. Only issues are, late game lag (can be solved by lowering graphics etc.) and npcs getting stuck (can be noticed easily) and some minor typos. The game deserves its current price tag. As an Early Access game it gets a 9 out of 10.

-----------------------------------------------------------
Warning, this review is out of date. The problems mentioned here may or may not be present in the current version.

Edit: Performance issues with having too many employees seems to be fixed or at least alleviated. Teleporting employees now only teleport to the door if they can't find a path to their desk or where they want to go, which is a good thing. Late game seems like a bother because of the training room and how employees get so little experience from actually designing games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad games Tycoon


A building simulation with a little bit of skill building sims.

Like the game Theme Hospital but with computers instead and

the ability to upgrade your working conditions such as garage or office building.

You raise the stats of your people and produce a mass of games in hope of

being the best and keeping your business afloat. Story along the lines of

Game Dev Tycoon. All features of Game Dev Tycoon are in there including

Making your own system, doing side work, and  creating mass games that blow

peoples minds. Upgraded graphics and more open ended gameplay make this a

pretty good game. I like that I have a choice in what my people are going to do

and where. You can even pick employees with special skills and traits that you want.

I personally enjoy giving my employees what they need and even messing with them

when they do bad by taking away things like the bathroom. I love the new explination

system as it gives you more in depth information on things and offers beginners a

better understanding of what you are doing. I can't really say much about how to get

a perfect game but there are online  tutorials and such out there that you can look up.

You can  make the game easy or hard and cater to your desires of running a business

bankrupt or making it a success. I miss some of the cutesy graphics but I guess that the

new ones are just as good. I got frustrated at the move object function until I learned

how to turn it off as I kept selecting items I did not want and in a time sensitive game it

is not good for you to waste any precious seconds when in threat of bankruptcy. Also,

when you delete a room you get nothing for it. So if you spent 200000 on it and remove it

because it was too small, you lose 200,000. There is no way to enlarge or shrink a room.  So, in

my opinion it is just as good as their previous game but polished a bit for those seeking

better emersion and more stuff. I find myself stuck on it for hours when I play it and often

lose track of time as I micro manage my little simmies into an early grave.
