This game has been continually updated since my original review and there are some changes I would like to share (there are many more but these are some of the main ones I find)

- More info around Staff

Updated Conclusion
A fun game that has gotten better and better.  If you like tycoon games this is one I would recommend and is a load of fun even though it is still EA it is feature rich and stable.


Original EA Review

Quite a fun game, in similar vein to Games Tycoon but more expansive.

Essentially you start as a games developer in your garage and work your way up to mega corp.  You need to hire staff, match their skills to the various assignments and train them up.

You can build a large variety of rooms and need to decorate them to improve productivity (must like theme hospital).  Getting larger offices means you can build larger rooms and dedicated more staff to the room etc.

Also you need not focus only on game dev, you can also go the publishing route, publishing other developers games which is neat.

One thing I also like is once you have released a game and if you have publishing facilities you can re-release them later at a discount and also make bundles, thus increasing your profits for that game in the long run.

Still a few issues to sort out, a few bugs and also to address (which I believe has been) the fact once you reach mid-point the game gets easier and getting good score games is a bit too easy (again this is being fixed).

Overall a highly addictive game thus far.

I will update this review when the game is released but right now it is in a very good state for Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just want to get this out of the way: I know it's an Early Access game, so some of my issues I have with the game will hopefully be fixed.  Until these things are fixed, I only give it about a 51/49 Yes/No ratio.

I owned Game Dev Tycoon before this, and I can say Game Dev is better.  But if the bugs/glitches/simple things get worked out, I could see this being better after the full release.

I'll try to make it simple.

Goodness:
+ Quite in depth compared to Game Dev
+ You can buy out other companies...succumb to my money: You keep the 1 and 2 star games, and I'll save the others for my company to make moneys ^_^
+ You get to build your studio

Gripes/Complaints
- When you build your studio, you have to completely retool it EVERY TIME you get more space.
- Simple things like clicking on the X to get out of a window only work about 50% of the time (HUGE issue)
- Translation to English is fairly poor.  Needs VAST improvement (GODZILLA ISSUE!)

Overall, think about getting the game, but unless you're patient enough to hope for updates in the future, you may feel a slight buyer's remorse.  I know I did until I sat back and looked at the big picture.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This is a long review so if you plan on reading read to the end

So this is a game I had picked up recently due to the interest I had had in it a while back. Playing games like this I find pretty enjoyable and  have done my fair share of Game Dev Tycoon, seeing this I immediately jumped to the conclusion that this was a rip off of that very game.

And boy was I wrong

So not only is this a game that takes the functions of Game Dev Tycoon and other Game Dev Sims it improves on it greatly allowing you to go into a deeper creation of your games, although not too far away from where it's aging older brother set the benchmark. By this I mean the ability to impliment copy protection for your games allow it to be released in other languages because it isn't all about the english speaking world and above all else it expands on what Game Dev does with it's combinations.

What does this mean? Well this is quite simple where Game Dev had the massive list of topics with the  5 root genres with the 6th researchable one of casual games coming into effect early on along with Multi-genre and MMO being unlocked later into the game, Mad Games Tycoon  goes balls to the wall with the progression of time since Game Dev's release these roots have branched off  to a collection of 16 genres for you to combine with one another to experiment and create the best games, and as time goes on maybe this will increase even more.

The Key element of this gameplay however is the other side to it, Game Dev is you sitting at your desk making money by making good games and then having you move into a bigger space and hire more people to sit at deska and help you make money, that may be putting it bluntly and to be fair there is other stuff to do like research and so on but stripped to it's core that is game dev. Mad Games Tycoon however decides to borrow elements from the late Maxis'  collosal franchise of the sims where you have to care for these people in more depth, you give people the multitude of rooms to work in along with a bathroom and break room as well as tending to their needs so their will to work for you is great this hopefully allowing you to get more done in your games and tilt the tide to get that higher rating and more money.

There is however one issue with this game that I have and that could partially be blamed on me as well. Mad Games Tycoon at the moment of me writing this review has no tutorial mode and if it does I can't find it, It does have an easy mode option which starts you off in an office space however but that really doesn't do much when it comes to learning the mechanics and the key gameplay elements. it took me a while to find out how to even build a room to work in let alone make a game and even then the sliders are easy to work around, but i wasn't too sure on how it would work. With words either side of the bar  I was unsure if moving it closer to one way meant it was a higher priority or that it meant it was a lower one because of the way Game Dev worked with the bigger bar meaning more time, and i'm honestly still not sure to this day.

Don't let this bring you down as eventually when you learn how the game works you can easily get into the game even with the difficulty. all of these games are the same fundementally with the rinse and repeat and if you don't succeed try again aproach with the idea that someday you will hit it big and from then it is smooth sailing.

Overall then this is a strong game even in it's early access state and is in strong standing within the Game Dev Games, although this review constantly made comparison to Game Dev  it does not mean I think of it as a worse game, I would honeslty say I believe that Mad Games Tycoon in it's current form is on par even without the tutorial and I really hope to see this game through to a full release where then it could take it's place on the throne of where Game Dev Tycoon currently resides

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I bought this game I found it to be really fun. It had many features, reminded me of the games from 1990's, when graphics where far from what they are now, but the idea and fun factor were everything in the games.

Mad Games Tycoon is changing rapidly. Developer adds features, polishes the ones that are already in, and it is a really, really good game. Personally I can recommend it to anyone who loves tycoons. But be warned - THIS GAME IS ADDICTIVE!

EDIT:

I came back to the game after many months of not playing... as I wrote before - it changes at a very fast pace. Now it's a pretty much complete game that is extremely addictive and fun. I really do love it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game reminds me of the games in my childhood. If you'd like to play games so called 'tycoon', this game is good for you. This game follows the common track of tycoon games. Money, hiring, facilities, development... so it's easy to get used to this game. Yeah, unfortunately, this feature is its weakness, too. Of course, this is early access and I know I have to endure some uncomfortable ones... but where is a tutorial? Although this is quite simple and easy to play, just a short tutorial is needed in every game. I didn't know how to set up my office so I thought it was a kind of bugs.  Moreover, the more employees you hire, the slower this is. Now I'm in the biggest office with about 40 employees but its speed is too slow for me to play this anymore. I recommend it but only for tycoon lovers and ones who are sick of complicated games. If you are not... well whatever.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions are that the feature list is exstensive and very enjoyable althrough streamlining of controls and visuals is key to this as feels a bit clunky but regular updates could solve this Have played game dev tycoon and game go makers I feel have to get used to this more sim like style again but seems good, a story mode would be nice as well as sandbox mode will update but can recommend this game for the fun factor and it's exstensive feature list,

UPDATED REVIEW 14/08/15
I still recommend this game very much recent patches are streamlining the interface without loss of features plus bug patches, Late game play is when it becomes more fun it all comes together and I can see the developers vision for the game and interconnected dynamic company system that has you wanting to exspand your company also leads to many choices in where you want to take your company.
The base game as it is is very playable, this is probably the most unrestrictive dev game out there still a little tricky getting started but once past the learning stage the game becomes more and more in depth than you initially realise with amount of connectivity within your company rooms, selling owm hard copy games, buying shares, all the game development feautures so on
This is almost the dream developer game just needs a little more polish

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was a big fan of Game Dev Tycoon, which I found to be a somewhat simplistic but easy to pick up and play simulator of being a game developer.

Mad Games Tycoon expands on this concept by adding in the capability to physically build the office you work in, assign space to specific tasks like R&D, Graphics, Sound, Motion Capture, Production, etc., and expands on the concept presented by earlier game development sims.

It's not an extremely difficult game, I didn't find it very hard to look up and have over $11Bn in money, and I'd love it if they had a larger top end building size -- I found it difficult to effectively set up a game development firm that was working on multiple games at a time, because of the size constraints near end-game.

Regardless, I enjoyed this very much and am excited to continue playing in early access as the developer seems to consistently update with big features.  Just don't get too attached to your save games!  (It's early access, you signed up for that!)

Building your own engine is the best way to make money, gives you a chance to be open with trial and error, you get to make games obviously, but you can do more with them, give them better quality/gameplay exc. If you want to push yourself further, get into console development, costly but can be very profitable.

I got upto year 2187 because I was maximizing my staffs skills
But made alot of mad games on the way, profiting in over $9999mil
Made a few MMO's and added a couple of expansions with max content, was making average about $200mil with each MMO. So profit can easily be made there aswell, just getting there can be a pain, unless you make and sell engines, or know the right mix and match for games.

Overall I like what this game offers apposed to the others on the market, only flaw for me though is once you reach year 2015 things start to settle down and the game gets pretty dull, other devs are still making games but no new consoles come out. reviewText:
Early Access Review

For me personally this is the best 'Game Dev' type game out at the moment. It builds further on the foundations laid by previous IP's in this genre. Compared to these previous titles this game offers a lot of personilization and offers deeper gameplay even at this early access stage.

You decide how to build your office as well as design it a bit by placing down various specific interior objects from a nice variety. There are various types of rooms which all help in the process of designing and developing video games. Including but not limited to QA rooms to improve game quality and remove bugs; sound studio for better game audio, marketing; customer support; toilets (when you gotta go you gotta go); development office and more.

Regarding the game development itself you research new technologies which you then implement by making new game engines for your own use or for selling it to your competitors for some extra cash. Although in the beginning you most likely have to purchase game engines due to shortage of cash. When starting development you have the basics such as the genres, topics, which engine to use, game size, etc. But also small extras such as licenses to purchase from movies/sports to give your game an additional popularity boost. Further down you choose with sliders where you want to focus your efforts on during development. The game can receive additional bonuses with the help of the QA room and sound studio at the moment.

Once ready for production you give can decide how many copies to produce and even decide what the package should be like. Want to give your new to be loyal fans a t-shirt and a manual? Or screw the manual! Let them find out on their own and just give them a nice one dollar sticker with the game! Set the sale price which can be adjusted and voila, rake in the profits .. or the losses.

This game also has some negative aspects at the moment. In my opinion the UI could be a bit better. Sometimes it feels you need to click couple times more in order to view what you want to view.

When building new rooms it's very difficult to sense the size of it. It would be helpful if there was some kind of visible tile/grid pattern to help visualise it. Because of that I often make my rooms too small because all the objects are not bound by the tile system that is used when creating a room. Desk 1 can be 1.25 tiles in lenght while desk 3 can be 2.2 tiles in lenght. Obviously it's somewhat more 'realistic' to not have everything the same size but it does not help with object placement at all.

Once you found the way to make money early game then you're launched and it will become very easy financial wise. You can get loans in case you're short on cash but they're paid off very quickly if you know the previous mentioned way to make money and the loan interests could be a bit higher as well imo.

Last but not least the game advances - at least in my opinion - rather quickly through time. So your play sessions could last a bit short.

All in all the positive aspects definately outweigh the negative ones. I highly recommend this game, not only for what it has right now but also for what will come. The developers give frequent updates and you can be sure that after an update or two/three you'll have some extra content to guarantee a new play session.

Early Access Review

Gameplay: 8
Graphics: 7
Sound: 7
Depth: 11
Value: 11

It is hard to believe that this game is in early access because it already feels like a full fledge game. The game is very addicting as I have been playing it almost non stop since I got it. The game is well worth the price escpecially because there is still more to come. This game is like The Sims and Game Dev Tycoon had a child and that child then became a prodigy.

Pros: Lots of content pretty much equal to Game Dev Tycoon with mods. Building your own company is fun especially since you build it Sims style. More than enough content that the game could be considered a release game. Gameplay is very addictive and provides lots of upgrades to keep you playing for quite sometime. Will take awhile to reach the biggest building but that is a good thing.

(Just small annoyances)
Cons: During the building menu sometimes the game will not recognize how big you want to build a room but the confirmation box only makes this issue a small annoyance. Some menus seem a little clunky like not having a cancel button if you accidently click on an object. Tutorial is really short and leaves out some important items around self production. Making games as contracts never seems to be worth the trouble over regular contracts.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's still a lot of work to do, but this concept has got a lot of potential to become a knock-out fun time consumerer. It already is in a sort of way, but it's still a short-term addiction.

The interface is a shameless copy of Theme Hospital. Let's just be honest about that. But why not use something that has proven to be solid instead of reinventing the wheel? There's something very appealing in being in charge of a gaming company. You start from your garage, being small time and struggling to keep the annual figures in green colors. You have to work a way through developing games, hiring staff, expanding your business and getting fans.

The strength of these 'tycoon' games, is that they don't demand much graphical attention. What does demand attention, is detail. I want to have to make important decisions: do I take out a loan? Do I invest funds to reignite a game? Do I have to cut the budget by firing staff? Some elements of a typical Tycoon game already show, like deciding to take part in a yearly game convention and expanding your fanbase or the endlessly staring at figures and gauges towards planning your next move.

If you're a fan of tycoon- or simgames by any stretch of the imagination, you'll like this game. There's a satisfying depth in developing your own games and there are a lot of possibilities to do so. I can only recommend to the creator to add more depth. As much as possible. I mentioned Theme Hospital. Remember how you were able to turn up the heating at a certain expense? More heating means the people will feel better, but it presses on your budget. I want to be thinking about these managerial decisions. If that can be provided, this game can become a long-term addiction.

Some advices for enhancing the game: add a toggle gridline, show the measurements of rooms when designing them, add the option to redesign a room without having to delete it, being able to take out a loan, easy dispatch of staff (not having to pick them up one by one), more gamespeeds (the first speed still feels a bit too fast, especially later on in the game).

Keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR AT THE BOTTOM


First off I want to say that I think this is what Game Dev Tycoon should have been (mostly), and that it is THE best game tycoon to date.

Pros:
Nice aesthetics for a tycoon game, no lens flares and motion blur to be seen here

While it is simplified, it is a realistic simulation of the game industry as a whole.

Wide variety of developers and publishers

At the moment , the price point feels very appropriate (£10.99)

You can import your own logos, in the game files, look for a folder with lots of PNG files, and then download your own PNG files (not sure if other formats work)

Cons:
At the moment, there is no modding community, I am not sure if it is that there is no mod support at all or if the community is not big enough, but as someone who loves to mess around with game files, this is very disappointing to me.

At the moment, the end game is very lacking  and it is way too easy at the end. In my main save, it is 2006, I am sitting at about 2.5 billion dollars, 1.2 million fans and all of my games have been 90% or better for about 18 years, and this is at the hardest difficulty.

The game is really unoptomized at the moment, my computer can run simcity on high settings at 1080p at 60fps but it cant run this at fast" settings at 1336x768 and stay at 60
date: which really killed my experience.\n\nIn conclusion I think that this is the best game studio simulator at the moment
recommended:
but it does still need some work on expanding the content.



TL:DR Buy it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just can't stop coming back to Mad Games Tycoon. Every couple of months I find myself spending a week as flat out as I can on it. It is addictive and satisfying - exactly what a tycoon game should be!

The synopsis of the game is such. You are a small scale aspiring game developer working out of your garage. You need to make it big in the gaming industry and you do so by researching technological advances in both hardware and software. You employ the people who you believe will make you the best games and then you plan the game to be developed according to the current trends.

The devs have clearly struck a real good balance in so many aspects if you ask me. For example; sometimes you may think that you are onto a whopper of a game... only.... it flops - generally for understandable reasons. That is when time starts ticking and bad decision making would almost certainly spell  B.A.N.K.R.U.P.T.C.Y.  However, delving into some serious debt with the bank is an option. I mean what is the difference between going bankrupt with a debt of $200k or going bankrupt with a debt of $1.5m? (The answer is nothing - except of course for the differing amount but that is irrelevant as it has no impact upon you). What I am coming to is that the extra borrowed cash used to make a good game has been enough to bring the company back into the black and I have gone on to build a massively successful gaming company thereafter. What is my underlying message?  THE GAME IS FUN AND REWARDING!!

Devs don't read the next statement.  I have gotten my money's worth many times over already IMO and yet the game is still in Early Access!!  Well worth the money for a really cool tycoon game. Can't wait for the next.

10/10 for Replayability
7/10 for User Interface
10/10 for Developer Continuous Dedication

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I have to say that I really like this game. I bought this game the day after the release on steam, ended up playing it for a while and thought it was pretty fun.  There were a couple features lacking then, and some problems with a couple other things at the time. However, unlike a lot of the Early Access Games that get dropped when the developers feel like they did enough or got enough money; Eggcode has had updates since the release.

To me it seems that the developers are open to ideas that the community has and would look into adding it if they think it would work well with the game. They also arn't shy from hearing about the bugs in the game people find, for me though the only real 'bug' I found was just a missing word, only because I was looking to hard at the history log at like 2 am. Sometimes the controls can be spotty but they always end up getting better overtime. Overall I have no real qualms about the game and very much like where it is heading.

If you where to ask which early access developer I like the most It would probably be these guys because I have seen the changes it has taken place in the past year. This would be on my Recommendations for early access games or just Fun games in general.

Keep up the good work! :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, its a lot like Game Dev Tycoon but with the ability to build your own office and a few interesting options, such as creating and selling game engines and buying licenses for movies and the like to make games for.

The first 10 years are really fun and challenging, but at this point the end game is quite broken.

Once you can afford R&D you can easily stay ahead of the game engine curve, so every game you make gets a 90+ rating and earns mega bucks. Then you can spend that money on a production facility and cut out the publishers, which is super low risk and earns way to much money. Finally, half your building is devoted to servers for your MMO subscribers, and you are earning millions more in passive income than you know what to do with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good and captivating game! Not only do you design and publish your own games, but you rather manage a game studio. You design the different rooms and decide how many people should work in the different departments. You build rooms for marketing, support, graphics, sounds & music and many more, whom you can assign different tasks, Do you want to design two games at once? Not a problem at all.
As the game goes on, you won´t need a publisher anymore as you can produce your games on your own. Furthermore, you can be the publisher of someone else´s game. This all is a guarantor for your financial well-being.
The most interesting aspect of the game are the different ways you will gain your money on. Not only a good game will earn you money, but eg. a good engine will make your competitors buy it and cut you in the profits of their games.

People who like to design their own games will like Mad Games Tycoon. However, it will develop its full potential only if you love to manage a bigger company.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people are going to compare Mad Games Tycoon to Game Dev Tycoon, and it's understandable why. They're both tycoon games based around game development. So the question is- which is better?

That's a difficult one.

Mad Games Tycoon definitely feels like a much deeper game. Unlike Game Dev Tycoon, you can actually build your office, which is a plus. You can also have multiple teams of people working on different things, instead of everyone working on the same thing, which is a huge plus. However, the actual game making part feels a little more satisfying in Game Dev Tycoon. With Game Dev Tycoon, you have to adjust things every so often in the game making process, while in Mad Games Tycoon, you do everything at the start and you wait. Admittedly, with the ability to have multiple groups of people doing multiple things, it doesn't feel like you're just sitting around and waiting for the most part, but I've had a few moments where I got rather bored just waiting for a game to get finished.

The one big thing that Mad Games Tycoon has going for it is that features are still being added. I've had the game for a week, maybe a week and a half, and it's already seen two updates that have changed up the gameplay significantly. Game Dev Tycoon, as good as it is, is a finished game. Sure, you can add some mods to the game to keep it fresh, but what you see is what you get, and it's all you're going to get. Mad Games Tycoon, on the other hand, is still evolving, still making changes to keep the game fresh, and that's why I prefer Mad Games Tycoon to Game Dev Tycoon.

The game's not perfect by any stretch of the imagination. There are some things I wish they made a little more clear, the lack of mod support is kind of a bummer (Though, it still being in development, I can understand) and sometimes the staff gets upset by silly things, but I've plugged a bunch of time into this game and I plan to plug a bunch more into it. Definitely worth picking up.

This game gets very hard after you have around 20 million dollars. Lots of micro-management. Would like for that to be slightly better.

Edit 2:
Did not realize you could have more than one desk per room. Wow I'm dumb...Anyways, that takes off the mass amount of micro-management. This game is truly great. 10/10

Edit 3:
Yea...went back to fix typos. Just one quick thing: The amount of updates parallels to that of Unturned (Another great game). They constantly update the game, adding new stuff (and bug fixes). It gotten immensely improved in the past 2 months. I'm probably getting redundant by this point, so here's the end of the review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you’ve played previously games like Game Dev Tycoon or GamersGoMakers then you already know what to expect.  If you haven’t, then this puts you as a game developer, starting out in the early 1980’s.  You begin small, producing small, simple games, from small, simple premises with appropriately early gaming technology.  As time goes on (assuming you don’t go bankrupt) you have the opportunity to expand, by hiring more people, researching new technology and moving into bigger premises.

Visually, Mad Games Tycoon is better looking than those other games.  Another area where this differs from the aforementioned games is that with Mad Games Tycoon, you have to manually create each room and place the appropriate furniture in it.  Over time, your staff will complain about wanting things, like plants or heating, which you’ll have to place in the room, so you’ll need to make sure you create a room big enough.  Not too big, though, because in the early stages, you only have limited space for your rooms.

Eventually, you’ll have the opportunity to produce and distribute your own games instead of going through a publisher, as well as creating MMO’s hosted on your own servers.

This game is still in early access, and while it should be obvious what that means, it’s apparently not obvious to some.  Early access means the game is still in active development.  So, new features will be added and existing ones may be altered or even removed.  You might even find your save games get ruined sometimes, forcing you to start again.  The game is NOT a finished product, which is why it’s in early access.  You’ll almost certainly run into bugs from time to time, and features that aren’t available or aren’t working as intended.  The most important thing to know about early access games is this: are the developers actively working on it?  The answer for Mad Games Tycoon is definitely ‘yes’.  Updates are regularly being released, which are usually both fix bugs as well as adding new features.  This is important, because I’ve seen early access games where the updates concentrate on one but not the other, causing the game to suffer as a result.

The game is still very much playable in its current state, but it’s by no means finished, and nor is it perfect as yet.  It would be really good, for example, to have better feedback as to why your game was terrible, or indeed why it was so good.  It’s not necessarily easy to work out exactly why your previous game did as well, or as badly, as it did.  Hopefully that aspect of the game will get worked on in time to come.  I know too many early access games have died or taken forever to do anything, but I’ve seen nothing so far to suggest that this game will be the same; on the contrary, I’m confident that we will indeed see a finished product in time, and a damn good one.  But please keep in mind, if you buy a game in early access then you’re paying money for something which may or may not actually get finished, or finished in the way you were expecting.  It’s always going to be a gamble, but in this instance, it’s one I was happy to make.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's write a quick review:

At this stage I would give 8/10 in this game.

Pros:
- Nice graphics and sounds. Nothing big, but fits well into the game.
- I do not feel the pressure to release a game. I can spend time on enhancements.
- There are just enough areas the game covers, from game engine development to production.
- Quite good interface. It's easy to reach anything.

Cons:
- It is a bit annoying that after I finished a game, my development team cannot do anything if I select 'release later'. My team should improve the game, develop bug fixes, add new features, etc...
- The music team cannot finish their work if I choose 'release the game' even if I set a long, lets say '24 weeks later' option. The whole game release process should be revised.
- The review should come after I finished everything, even improvements! Now it happens immediately after I selected 'release game'.
- I am not sure, but it seems that even if I started repaying my bank loan, when I have enough money to repay the whole amount, the original amount will be taken from my account.

Improvements:
- There are tons of topics to research. With a 4-member-team I can easily reach a point when I do not really have anything to do just reasearching new topics. A small checkbox with title Continue topic reasearch when finished" would come handy
date: so I do not need to go through the research topic procedure in every 3 seconds.\n- There are areas that need some additional help information. Bank loans (about the amounts that need to be payed)
recommended: production (how much production capabilities per week I have)
hoursPlayed: buying properties (how big each offices are) and similar things."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good and captivating game! Not only do you design and publish your own games, but you rather manage a game studio. You design the different rooms and decide how many people should work in the different departments. You build rooms for marketing, support, graphics, sounds & music and many more, whom you can assign different tasks, Do you want to design two games at once? Not a problem at all.
As the game goes on, you won´t need a publisher anymore as you can produce your games on your own. Furthermore, you can be the publisher of someone else´s game. This all is a guarantor for your financial well-being.
The most interesting aspect of the game are the different ways you will gain your money on. Not only a good game will earn you money, but eg. a good engine will make your competitors buy it and cut you in the profits of their games.

People who like to design their own games will like Mad Games Tycoon. However, it will develop its full potential only if you love to manage a bigger company.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's write a quick review:

At this stage I would give 8/10 in this game.

Pros:
- Nice graphics and sounds. Nothing big, but fits well into the game.
- I do not feel the pressure to release a game. I can spend time on enhancements.
- There are just enough areas the game covers, from game engine development to production.
- Quite good interface. It's easy to reach anything.

Cons:
- It is a bit annoying that after I finished a game, my development team cannot do anything if I select 'release later'. My team should improve the game, develop bug fixes, add new features, etc...
- The music team cannot finish their work if I choose 'release the game' even if I set a long, lets say '24 weeks later' option. The whole game release process should be revised.
- The review should come after I finished everything, even improvements! Now it happens immediately after I selected 'release game'.
- I am not sure, but it seems that even if I started repaying my bank loan, when I have enough money to repay the whole amount, the original amount will be taken from my account.

Improvements:
- There are tons of topics to research. With a 4-member-team I can easily reach a point when I do not really have anything to do just reasearching new topics. A small checkbox with title Continue topic reasearch when finished" would come handy
date: so I do not need to go through the research topic procedure in every 3 seconds.\n- There are areas that need some additional help information. Bank loans (about the amounts that need to be payed)
recommended: production (how much production capabilities per week I have)
hoursPlayed: buying properties (how big each offices are) and similar things."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you’ve played previously games like Game Dev Tycoon or GamersGoMakers then you already know what to expect.  If you haven’t, then this puts you as a game developer, starting out in the early 1980’s.  You begin small, producing small, simple games, from small, simple premises with appropriately early gaming technology.  As time goes on (assuming you don’t go bankrupt) you have the opportunity to expand, by hiring more people, researching new technology and moving into bigger premises.

Visually, Mad Games Tycoon is better looking than those other games.  Another area where this differs from the aforementioned games is that with Mad Games Tycoon, you have to manually create each room and place the appropriate furniture in it.  Over time, your staff will complain about wanting things, like plants or heating, which you’ll have to place in the room, so you’ll need to make sure you create a room big enough.  Not too big, though, because in the early stages, you only have limited space for your rooms.

Eventually, you’ll have the opportunity to produce and distribute your own games instead of going through a publisher, as well as creating MMO’s hosted on your own servers.

This game is still in early access, and while it should be obvious what that means, it’s apparently not obvious to some.  Early access means the game is still in active development.  So, new features will be added and existing ones may be altered or even removed.  You might even find your save games get ruined sometimes, forcing you to start again.  The game is NOT a finished product, which is why it’s in early access.  You’ll almost certainly run into bugs from time to time, and features that aren’t available or aren’t working as intended.  The most important thing to know about early access games is this: are the developers actively working on it?  The answer for Mad Games Tycoon is definitely ‘yes’.  Updates are regularly being released, which are usually both fix bugs as well as adding new features.  This is important, because I’ve seen early access games where the updates concentrate on one but not the other, causing the game to suffer as a result.

The game is still very much playable in its current state, but it’s by no means finished, and nor is it perfect as yet.  It would be really good, for example, to have better feedback as to why your game was terrible, or indeed why it was so good.  It’s not necessarily easy to work out exactly why your previous game did as well, or as badly, as it did.  Hopefully that aspect of the game will get worked on in time to come.  I know too many early access games have died or taken forever to do anything, but I’ve seen nothing so far to suggest that this game will be the same; on the contrary, I’m confident that we will indeed see a finished product in time, and a damn good one.  But please keep in mind, if you buy a game in early access then you’re paying money for something which may or may not actually get finished, or finished in the way you were expecting.  It’s always going to be a gamble, but in this instance, it’s one I was happy to make.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon has quite a bit of content for an early access game. I have actually put in 29 hours into. I would have played more but I plan on waiting a while until more content is inserted into the game. Even though, this is an early access game I still highly reccomend it to anyone who likes management games or Game Dev Tycoon or just anyone who ever dreamed of starting their own video game company. You get to hire you want, make good and bad games, design the inside of your building, sell engines you make and expand your company. Two thing do not like so far but I know it will be added in the future is the fact that there is a certain point in the game you start to run out of stuff to research for new video game engines. It just felt weird that it was the year 2014 and my game engine still had a 32-bit color support and not 64-bit. Also I believe the option to create a free to play game in the game is still locked and also the option to add a graphics studio to enhance any of your video games in development is locked. However, the game is still in early access and theres a lot of features that are locked now but will be added later so just be patient. After the amount of hours I put into it this game I could confidently say that my investment in this game is more than worth it. So do yourself a favor and give the developers your money.

****UPDATE**** 4/25/2016
This game has improved a LOT since my first review in June? July? idk. Anyways they added more features like new rooms you could build such as a music studio and a animation room. I also like the build a console feature even though it feels incomplete. For example there is not that  many custom designs you could do for the case. Also it feels weird that after I make a console I don't have to produce it like any game you produce you just develop it and it magically sells. One thing I also noticed that i thought felt wrong was that after the year 2010 theres not much else you can research. Yes there other stuff you can research but they are few and far between which makes the research department useless late game. Hopefully more late game research features gets added later which most likely will happen since the developers regularly update the game. Overall I can't wait to see how much different the game will be further down the line.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Game Dev Tycoon, you will probably like this more. It isn't the same as GDT, there's a lot more management. You build your rooms add desks, hire staff etc. You can buy or make your own game engines, with the option to sell the engine and get a percentage of the AI developers games. There is more control over the games you create - you can buy licenses to increase the appeal of the game.

Currently the game is Early Access, and will probably stay that way for a long time although the devs do dish out updates often. With that MGT has a lot of problems:

- looks like English isn't the devs native language, you can understand the messages just about though
- massive amount of annoying messages that pop up, whenever your staff complete any project or training, any new research available, when a console is going to be released, has been released is going to be taken off the market, when it has been taken off the market, when your games get taken off the market, when your engines sell, each time your game stops until you click ok (and project/training messages require 2 ok's)
- research technology isn't consistent, particularly early on. By the time you finished your research and created an engine for it at the beginning it is already obsolete, but after year ~2000 there's hardly anything new that comes out.
-theres currently no point in doing AAA games as there is only 20 different end game technologies available.
-they recently added new consoles and stuff, which doesn't do anything for you other than more annoying messages.
-Easy and normal have no challenge to them whatsoever, and there's no end game score like in GDT. If you haven't made 200 mil by 2005 you probably wanna check your pulse. Legendary mode is rediculous, although I've only had 1 good go at it. You can make games without engines and sell them for a profit so long as your staff are fully trained, you can do contracts and make engines to sell for like 5% profit at the beginning, but everything else fails. After my best go i made a few mil, made the best engine, fully trained my staff and made a AA game with everything in it and it failed and I went bankrupt. In Easy it's the opposite, no matter what you do you will still make a profit.
-when you get a larger building and fill it with stuff the game's performance drops through the floor.

To summarise, this game is worth it if you are into sim/tycoon games. The devs do update the game often, but in it's current state only die hard tycoon game fans will clock anywhere near as many hours as i have put into this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun, but only for a very short time...

It's 2015. Every game I release that does not sell 100 Mio. Copies in the first year is considered a failure. But that's still ok, since my studio hasn't released a game with a rating less than 90% since the early 80's. Unfortunately, I can't releaser any more games, even in the biggest office and though I demolished almost all other rooms, I can't build any more servers for my subscription sheeple. And since I closed down all the other studios early on, there hasn't been a game of the year in...years, really.
So I guess, I'd be a little more fun if there was something to discover after 2001, a way to improve something instead of just repeating what you just did, like dismissing a marketing campaign every 5 seconds. But you get to develop something like 75 games before you figure out the perfect settings, and for that time, it was great fun.
The bad:
* the default speed is way to fast, and space does not pause the game (hint: '1'
does, though)
* assigning people to rooms is hell
* re-assigning people to rooms after some training comes down to 'who are you and where did you work before'
* no work queueing. (actually, that is not true. Almost no work queueing)
* after a while, it get's repetetive as ....
* appearently, the world of video games has not made any advancements after 2001.

Still, you get almost 30 (simulated :) years, in which teh game is great fun.

Last's about a weekend.

First of I was about to buy Game Dev Tycoon, then discovered this and read in the reviews that it is better and has more options, so I went for this one.
I know the devs are still updating it and such so I hope the things I will point out will be fixed in the near future.
I'm at a bit bigger building but by far not the last one and already have everything unlocked except being able to produce my own consoles.
Unfortunately at this point the game starts to lag horribly (it is definitely not the pc since I usually play way more demanding games than this). I'm assuming it got worse because I have more rooms and staff members now, therefore more things are happening. I turned down the graphics and tweaked some things off but no change.
I hope this can be fixed since it is getting quite hard to move the camera around and click on rooms to give tasks.

Since there are more buildings to unlock and I have currently everything researched, I hope there are more coming soon. I'm currently in the year 2013.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of tycoon games, this is a must!

Pros:
- Console development
- Great development team who updates the game regularly
- Good sense of replayability
- Ability to branch out into many different aspects of the video game industry
- The many rooms such as marketing, customer support, quality assurance, research, motion capturing, + more, immerces you into feeling like you're running an actual games company
- It is more friendly and easy to beautify your company
- the game is easy to pick up and well worth the money
- You can find yourself playing way more than intended
- You can train employees in the skills that matter to their job
- You can make MMOs and addons
- You can patch your game after release as well as develop updates

It's safe to say there are many positives, it is well worth a purchase and the development team deserve a thumbs up, there are many more aspects of the game I have not listed. It seems that the little features that you notice go a long way.



Final review:
The game is worth the money, and cannot be compared to game dev tycoon as Mad Games Tycoon is something unique in itself that allows you to branch into many different aspects of the gaming industry.

Conclusion - WORTH BUYING

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm on my first playthrough of this game and I love it!
It probably helps if you're a game nerd and a lover of tycoon games, like me.

You start of in your (parents?) garage and work your way up from there.
The controls are very easy. And there are lots of thing to develop.
You can take contracts and produce games for others, but also release games and consoles yourself.
Hire the best staff and train them to become your masterminds. Make sure the right person is in the right place.

I find this game very satisfying and I have a hard time closing down my laptop and going to bed haha.

Pros:
*Easy to learn the basics.
*Many different games to develop.
*Lots of hardware and software to research.
*Easy to get caught up" and play for to long.

Cons:
*With a huge company it tends to get a bit messy on the screen.
*Quite hard to master the development strategies for high selling games.
*Some graphic glitches where staff teleport through walls
date:
but no big deals.
*Easy to get "caught up" and play for to long.

Overall:
I give this game a score of 7.67 / 10 for being very fun."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a fun game. My main complaint is the dialog boxes. Once you really start to take off and you get to the point where you're bringing in huge amounts per game, naturally you want to expand to the largest location available and really develop your studio as much as possible. However, when you have that many projects running at once, the dialog boxes get so out of control that the game is nearly unplayable. Needs an option to disable game-interrupting notifications.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never written a review before in my life, for literally any product. I don't fill out online surveys. I don't respond well to people calling me and asking if I have time to answer some questions. I NEVER GIVE FEEDBACK. Yet, here I am, writting this review. That should say something about how passionately I feel about this game. This is exactly what I have been searching for. I love it. I cannot stop playing it. It's absorbing my life and ruining my sleep schedule. If you like logistics you'll love this game.

It's still early access, but it's already a great game. I don't know if developers read these reviews, but I have only a few complaints.
1. When your company gets large and people are wandering around it becomes impossible to find people and move them to a different room.
2. I feel the game is paced too fast. I think that one game year goes by in 20 minutes? I haven't really timed it out, but it is too quick. I think that they should slow down how long you get to spend in one year, or at least add the ability to adjust the game pace (making faster makes the game more challenging).

Those are my two biggest complaints. And they're not even complaints. I don't know how much longer they plan to keep it in early access, but this is a well put together game right now. I can think of a lot of features it would be cool to have (for example the ability to release early access games, the ability to develop mobile app games), but I can't think of anything this games needs to complete it.

If you like the builder/management sim type games, you will love this game.

You will be obsessed.

It's a somewhat hesitant yes. I certainly had great fun with the game for a few hours, but I wont be coming back to it.

I mean for long stretches the games was fun, but in the end when I got MMO's it went downhill. MMO's are simply too overpowered. My world of warcraft-ripoff made well over 800 million for me and all I had to do was open more develoing rooms so I could develop several consecutive MMO:s and develop expansions for them and the money just kept rolling in. Across all my active MMO:s I had well over 15 million subscribers so it kind of feels like I cant really lose at this game now.

But up until that point it was a fun, albeit somewhat unpolished, game. Maybe I'll revisit in a year or so when maybe things have changed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've booted this game up once only so far, and have 13 hours in game. That should tell you quite a lot.

This game is quite similar to Game Dev Tycoon except has a whole lot more. The rooms are customisable and your staff will require different furniture and working conditions to keep them happy. It has quite a steep learning curve at first and I failed miserably with my first 3 games. As the game progresses and as you hire more staff, you'll need to be ontop of several different tasks at once, all with time limits. Games that have been released will need advertising and game updates to keep them in the market. If you publish your own games you'll need to keep an eye on how many are being made, if you have enough stock etc. The game will pull you in, and has a lot of replayability.
Finally making a smash hit game was hard to do but felt so damn good.

Definately worth the money.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an aspiring game designer I find this game to be an inspiration. What better type of game to make than one about making games? Besides, I find this very type of game interesting as it allows me to simulate my dreams. This game is very much for the players as well, as any ideas or suggestions are considered by the development team. Although simple I feel as though it is the perfect game to begin your—Eggcode’s—development experience with.
Mad Games Tycoon starts you off in a garage in the 1980s where you must claw your way up through the game industry by starting your own company and making history. Creating revolutionary games is all the fun with this game. Being able to create a legacy for others to be inspired by as well as making the games which changed the industry in your own way are the reasons this game is so addictive. The game is quite easy as well, making all of the complex tasks very easy for beginners; of course there are exceptions further along in the game whereby the expansion of your company requires more elements to be available. The ability to unlock more aspects of the game in a more controlled manner by forcing players to earn money and play for lengths of time before they can move onto more complex tasks creates a buffer for new players to understand the mechanics of the game industry better. I did find however that when I began first creating my games they would usually go bust and I would have to rework contracts to regain money, I now realise that this game utilises the term you need to spend money to make money, and it works.
Their depiction of the tools available is quite well done in fact, it excites me. Being able to change and modify so many details such as the toilets for example captures the side of me that loves management games. The ability to develop patches, updates, language packs, sequels, as well as undertaking contracts tugs on my perfectionist personality when it comes to games, so making sure they’re ‘up-to-date’ creates the atmosphere of me almost being there. The endless immensity of content in this game leaves me wanting more, and the actual experience far outweighs the realistic visual quality some of today’s games may offer, especially for such a low price.
This game honestly propels my excitement for my own career through the roof. Being able to tell stories and make so many people happy in such an interactive way is thrilling. Mad Games Tycoon gives me encouragement to create games which can redefine gaming; a big dream yes, but at least I’m aiming somewhere. This experience provides me with insight into what can be done with a little work: being able to create worlds, or go back to different times, it’s all merely based on imagination and creativity and this game shows me that Eggcode has created a very tantalising experience—one that shows they create promising hope of future games as alluring as this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played it 12 hours straight on day one.. A few minor translation errors and there are some areas of the game that are not intuitive, but become clear when they come along later in gameplay. For example there is no point in holding the publishing of a game early on, if you do not yet have departments for graphics, music and QA etc. It is not immediately clear on how repackaging and bundling old games works. The purpose of the desk in the Home Office is also not explained, it is not actually used but applies a modifier based on the quality of the desk used. Those things being said, it is a rather enjoyable game I'd say even in it's current 'early access' state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a somewhat hesitant yes. I certainly had great fun with the game for a few hours, but I wont be coming back to it.

I mean for long stretches the games was fun, but in the end when I got MMO's it went downhill. MMO's are simply too overpowered. My world of warcraft-ripoff made well over 800 million for me and all I had to do was open more develoing rooms so I could develop several consecutive MMO:s and develop expansions for them and the money just kept rolling in. Across all my active MMO:s I had well over 15 million subscribers so it kind of feels like I cant really lose at this game now.

But up until that point it was a fun, albeit somewhat unpolished, game. Maybe I'll revisit in a year or so when maybe things have changed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

15 hour play through the first night(3 am)...Its pretty fun!

Thought i would give some thoughts on this early access game.

saying its a GDT rip off is like saying every shooter(insert genre) is a rip off of each other.

This game has plenty of its own ideas and content to set it apart. Ideas and content i was hoping would have gotten added to gdt, but never happened.

It took me a couple of tries to get a playthrough going. trying to figure out the mechanics when making a game. 15 hours in it is going smoothly.

my biggest gripes with the game are,

: Building the rooms. the placement is a little tough, as the curser and floor arent lining up where you think they are.

: Task menus.  they block your staff. i accidently released a game (while polishing it) when trying to pick a guy up to               move.


nothing has been game breaking. with a little more content & polish this will be a great game.

for now   8\10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a more realistic take on game development simulation than what was seen in Game Dev Story or Game Dev Tycoon. I played the hell out of both games, but both games lack the amount of depth Mad Games Tycoon brings to the table. It combines the core aspects of Game Dev Story/Tycoon and adds in the ability to manage different divisions of your studio. It also adds the ability to publish games, market them, sell game engines, and a lot more. It takes sometime to grasp everything, but if you stick with it you become addicted. Mad Games Tycoon can use a couple more points in the visuals department, particularly with its UI. The graphics are actually pretty good. The main menu is fugly though and the game menus are a little cluttered and not totally polished. It's early access though and this is just nitpicking. I'm just glad this game exists; it’s totally what I was looking for. If you liked Game Dev Story/Tycoon and would like something more in depth then try out Mad Games Tycoon.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo this game has been updated quite a bit over the past year and I thought I'd update my review. This game is in one word awesome.  If you enjoyed Game Dev Tycoon you'll have a lot of fun, (dare I say even more fun?)  playing this game as you rise to the title of a true tycoon. Crush your enemies, see them driven before you, and hear the lamentations of their women! Buy out your competition then shut them down for good, or let them make games for your profit! Build a console that breaks the mold and take control of the hardware industry! Create the perfect game, with dozens of genres and even more topics to pick from you're sure to find a winner.  Customize your studio from the ground up: choose the logo, company name, and build your own offices!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who played Game Dev Story, then played Game Dev Tycoon (which was a copy of GD story), this I can say is not a copy at all. It used that Game Development genre and took it to the next level. This game can be played in so many ways, you can make games, produce games which could be your own or other companies. You can purchase shares of other companies  and produce their games or have them only make games for a console you develop. You create rooms for each type of office and there is just so much more.

It is slightly challenging due to the lack of tutorial for explaining what each thing is or does and some tutorials help in providing how to make games great but they don't know some of the features it seems as well. There are very minor issues with the clashing of objects when placing them down.

OVERALL, A MUST HAVE if you even think you like these type of games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

* EDIT * I did some testing and it seems like how you make the game has nothing to do with how its scored.

3 times in a row i made a game that had a terrible combinations of genre and topic, didnt touch a single slide in the next section and randomly moved the slides in the graphics/music/gameplay section.

Each time my game got 91%...

This is something that MUST BE FIXED.

--------------------------------------------------------

So I bought this game today at around 9pm... It is now 5am... I dont regret a single thing.

I know this game is in early acces or whatever, but it has sooo much more than GDT in it.
Some things that I didnt really like are
- Buying engines... no point in making your own...
- I got 9 games in a row that were rated 91% ... Thats something that needs to be changed.
- I dont like creating the office space... Thats more personal preference but the whole way its done is quite bad to me..

Other than this the game was worth every cent. I cant wait for what the future holds for Mad Games Tycoon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the best of the game simulation titles that I have played and while comparable to Game Dev Tycoon it is more akin to Game Dev Story on Android devices. It has more variety, it allows you to build rooms yourself, it has a wider range of training parameters, and the story is considerably longer than other tycoon games. At six hours I just encountered the release of the PS2 where in other games we'd be finished the list of events.

That said the game can be much better. English is clearly not the first language of Eggcode (See event message for game release 3th World War 2") and there needs to be quite a few corrections. Secondly the animation and graphics of the people / employees is terrible. People barely look like people and females are only distinguishable by their names. The game allows you to succeed largely as a producer of engines if you don't have luck making games but I feel this could be expanded and improved to allow for engine marketing and support. Maybe even the design of periphreals to sell with the engine or game. Another issue is that the event messages are strictly limited to other game releases and profit reports. Eggcode should be looking at adding things like conventions
hoursPlayed: and direct interaction with the publishers. The game tracks publisher relationship but that doesn't seem to extend in functionality any further than how likely they are to produce a marketing campaign for your game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad Games Tycoon is different from games like Game Dev Tycoon. It has a more realistic approach like that your employees have to use the bathroom and if they find the room/building cold then they work slower. Although I find working 24/365 unrealistic as I don't think anyone is that passionate about games where they would work without at least taking a vacation in 30 years. Mad Games Tycoon has more ways of making money for example  you can make money off of engines by setting a certain % of profit sharing if people buy your engine and use it for their games. You can also make money from subscriptions from MMO although that needs some balancing.

The game is still in early access and so far I am happy with the way things are although there are some bugs and things that need balancing.

Would recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a massive timesink into this game I feel that Mad Games Tycoon makes for a signifigant updated version to Game Dev Tycoon. The consept of the two games are similar, but everything else within the game is much more complex in both tasks and mechanics. You are required to put in a lot of consistant imput, spend a lot of time thinking about growth, and for the perfectionist there is a lot of ways to micromanage, but the game is not built to require it either for the casual gamer making for a great balance.

While there are flaws such as how the charachers will get themselves hung up on some objects, I hardly consider such minutia an issue due to the fact that this is an early access game (as of writing this review). For those who loved Game Dev Tycoon, this is a must buy. Just remember when you start the game, there is a sudden learning curve (due to the fact that the early access lacks a detailed tutorial at the time of this review). So for the first time player, treat the first 2-3 starts as a dry run to learn the mechanics, the objects, the rooms, etc. For early access buyers, bear with the learning curve because once you pass the turn its a massive and enjoyable timesink.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you love game development and if you love Theme Hospital then you will love this one. Given this is early access and room for heaps of improvement is brutally obvious, the game is shaping up to a solid management simulation in the likes of Bullfrog creations. It even sprinkles some humor over the game to keep things interesting.

There is depth in gameplay which is missing from Game Dev Tycoon (another good game in its own right). You need proper planning and the game, in its current state, is unforgiving. You cannot resize rooms! Choices like should I place that expensive one star plant or the cheap one star plant?" become important as you grow a bond with your virtual employees. Sometimes you feel like rewarding them by throwing in an extra fan.

The game follows accurate history of game development and I felt nostalgic when I could easily relate to 16-bit graphics being a selling point.

I highly recommend you try it out and experience it for yourself but keep in mind : EARLY ACCESS"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Is this game worth it, you are wondering?

Yes. Yes it is. There is a lot of things you can do in this game.

On my current playthrough, I struggled early on to make games. Then I made an engine just so I didn't have to pay someone else to use theirs. Well... I was wrong - still had to pay to use even my own engine, but.... I soon had a steady source of income when other game companies started using my engine too! That was my main source of income, outside of contract jobs and such.

I actually made a handful of games. All of them got crap reviews... until I made one game. Sulibad the Wizard. I marketed the crap out of it. I was already like 5 million in debt to the bank, was considering starting a new game.... then that game was released....

I netted in nearly 20 million off of one game.

And the most rewarding feeling I have ever had in a game - my 20 million dollar grossing game scored an award for Best sound of that particular year (2007 I believe).

All in all, a good game. If you like management games like this, its worth grabbing for sure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't typically review a lot of games; others usually say all that needs to be said.

I'm making an exception here.

I saw this game and debated it, since I enjoyed 'Game Dev Tycoon' enough.

One of the best purchases I've made in a long time. I don't see any cons yet, which for an Early Access game (Which I usually avoid,) is outstanding in itself. It takes a little time to completely figure out how it functions, but that's because it's FAR more complex (In a great way,) then Game Dev Tycoon.

The amount and levels of control you have is great, highly useful.

I build games... and did horrible at the start. Stopped, Focused on game engines instead... did well. Went back to making more games, doing better but not great. Funding came more by the money made by my game engines.
After money... made money producing games, too. Still didn't make many games.

Years down the road... I'm now a economic powerhouse who has the best console, best RPG games (Which is my main focus,) and best production house in the world. 11/10 would build a company from scratch again and become another powerhouse.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter playing Game Dev Tycoon years ago, I always desired a successor that had more depth and options in how you can progress in the game. This game is everything I asked for, with the replayability being helped by the constant updates to the game. My one gripe with the game is that once you have the formula for success in your games, not making a profitable game, nevermind failing, is a non issue. This issue seems to have already started to be addressed with the addition of negative trends, so I have full faith that the game will be balanced further as it is developed. This game is worth every penny it is sold for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had this game for about 14 months and have seen it grow and change. The UI has gotten a lot worse, but the new things that they have added are REALLY impresive! I played the crap out of Game Dev Tycoon, and Game Dev story (Game Dev story is awful), and I thought that this one was the most indepth by far.

Console Development in this game has improved a ton and is probably the best console dev simulation out of any game that I have played. You have to research the different items and fetures for your console and then develope it. The only issue is with this is that there are very little of them! After 2020 passes all the fetures have been released. And that leaves you in a lot f trouble, because your console automaticly losses market share over time. So, you then have to make a new console; no big deal. But the problem wtih that is the next console you realese will be a copy and past of the last one, giving your console ♥♥♥♥♥♥ reviews and ultimately leaving the console dev part of the game unplayable! What I hope Egg Code does is put another layer onto console dev, like a Operating System, that you develope! You put a certain amount of money and time into the OS like you would while making an actual game. Mabye in the begining you could even buy an OS in the same way that you buy engines. And making OS's never ends, so that your console doesn't suck after a while. What would also be awesome would be OS updates!


But, the game development is pretty good. When initialy staring development you are aloud to pick and change a lot of stuff, including the languages that the game is made for, what engine you use, etc. Later in development you are also aloud to make big improvments, like making graphics studios and music studios to make the game look and sound better. Although I have played this game a lot, I still can not defeat legendary mode; it is litteraly impossible. It makes the bank barely give you any money, (and you will need it badly), and LITERALY caps the review at 80%! Oh, and one REALLY bad thing that they added, was caping the amount of updates that you can for a game! ♥♥♥♥ING get rid of that please!!

Now after the most recent update, (which added a hype system and marketing for consoles), I can say that it is the best game developement simulator that is on steam. I was happy to see that that Eggcode releases an update every one to two weeks. I would say to the hardcore and casual gamer that this game is a must! But, buy this game with a grain of salt, becasue you always suck in the first 10 hours that you play, until you memorize what types of games need what.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very Stable game, especially for an early access game. I'm a big fan of simulators and most of them are crap. This one is different and the Dev's have obviously made a commitment to quality versus just trying to turn a quick buck. What is lacking is an end game at this point, or true competition with other Studios in the game. Further, when you add production lines and start self producing games, it becomes a bit difficult to manage without larger buildings, or a more automated process.

The Dev's at this point could release the game as a full complete addition, and it would rival many of the sim games on Steam. But they promise more, and the sky is the limit as far as how far they take this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Take Game Dev Tycoon and Rollercoaster Tycoon, now put them together. You take the idea of developing games from Game Dev Tycoon, and you take the strategic building elements from Rollercoaster Tycoon.

I really liked Game Dev Tycoon, but it was lacking something. For instance, you cannot design your building in Game Dev Tycoon. The strategy was there, but there just wasn't enough

Mad Games Tycoon fixes this. The game is deep, and it can take awhile to learn how to play the best. This game is well worth it at full price, and if you find it on sale, grab it right away! This one is great!

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this game is early-access but it does not free a game from judgment.
This game is a step up from the game Mad Games Tycoon, though sadly it does not contain the ability to create your own console/computer.  But still, I did not and will not judge a game by it lokking or just is a copy of another game, it is content and the way that content is distributed throughout the game by it's engine.  The blend, in my view, is perfect.  However the following are the major flaws I have found to be quite irritating; you must be carefull when selecting options for what you want to be accomplished in a certain room, by opening that menu it pauses the game, but, it does not prevent you from picking up an object/staff member.  Then there is the lag generated by the moving boxes on the pressing machines, tha particle effects of a pressing machine, and from the progress/money icons generated from the staff/machines from progress/up-keep cost, respectivelly.  Next, the way pop-ups are handled in the way that the releases of consoles and the generation of money from a competitor.  I know that you can turn these off, but I belive that they could have added in, say, a ticker bar at the bottom that would not cause the game to pause during me looking up achievements or hurrying to a room to order a contract to be completed in order to avoid bankrupsty.  Finally, the way that games are created are based off of an irratating back/next button desicion screens, I sometimes miscount the number of features, or realise that the game I wanted was either to be market release only or MMO.  It would kinder that they replace the button system with a tab system.  But with the enjoyment/satisfaction I feel I would have to say 8.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the whole tycoon style of gaming, this isn't one to be overlooked!

Basic outline of the game:
The game has you start in your garage, you work for free (because you're that kind of guy!) and you possibly hire a few guys to help you out.  You research new graphical and sound techniques to keep up with the trends and work your way up in to a gaming powerhouse with your own motion capture studios and graphical studios, even being your own production company!

The similarities between this and other games of this genre such as Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story are many, the mechanics are the same, the goals are the same and you research the same sort of technology, genres etc.  The difference comes in that it feels a bit more in depth, it isn't just 3 sliders to determine what goes in to the game, there are a few more sliders, but the same sort of thing! Of course it does look a bit prettier as well, less like a Windows 8 store game and more like a real game, so it has eye candy going in its favour too.

Being early access it still has room for improvement and I'm sure it will come. Is it worth £10.99? At the moment, probably not, I don't feel it has enough pull" to keep me going for a long time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Had an odd moment playing this game. Was pricing a game engine, trying to decide how to get the most profit, when I realized this isn't how I want companies to act. I had more than enough money, MMO subscriptions alone would carry the company, I'd have to _work_ to make an unprofitable game. Yet, I was considering taking a 50% share with millions upfront....

Ended up releasing every engine type for free. Hope the non-existent people of the non-existent world get a richer gaming life because I got a memory worth keeping. Sometimes enough is enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a firm believer in that when it comes to Early Access, a review has to be about where the game is going, not where it's at.
Because it's early access, it's STILL in development.
But this is one of those games that I can review both sides of it

Where is it going:
This game is showing the potential to be an insanely great Tycoon game, with massive amounts of depth, intended more for a seasoned Tycoon player.
And if the developers listen to their community, it'll be a truly community shaped Tycoon game, with massive amounts of depth and features that the gamers want. (which is really what Early Access is all about, unfortunately, not every developer gets this)

Where it's at:
The game is rather stable, my computer can play it without crashing, or encountering many bugs at all (my computer is a 2013 high ender, it's due for an upgrade, but it's still really powerful) this is rare for a game so early in Alpha.
The game already has some really great things to play with, the core mechanics seem to all be present to my knowledge.

Where the game stands now, you can purchase it and have a lot of fun with it.

The game however has one downside that I personally hope gets addressed, progress on games, research, engines, general progression even progression relating to skills, is really slow, and this means that after finishing a game, you don't really get any real benefit from it in the skill department, your developers do get better at certain genres though, which is a separate system from the skill system.
And to add to that, you are often put in the situation of I have nothing to do and I'm bored
date: because I'm just watching things happen" while you wait for a game to complete or an engine to be fully coded
hoursPlayed: etc.\nand there needs to be things implemented so you the player have something to do while you wait (maybe a mini game
voteText: or just general things to do
helpfulPercent: click this
votesHelpful: this happens kinda thing
votesTotal: for example watering plants
votesFunny: collecting mail
commentsCount: something to keep you occupied)\n\nThe visuals are good enough
column16: but I personally believe they should upgrade the graphics if the developers get the chance
column17:
and aren't bogged down with everything else. I'd also like to be able to zoom in further.

Where is it going scoreboard:
Has the potential to be:
Visuals 8/10
Gameplay: 10/10
Depth and scope: 10/10
replayability: 9/10

Where it's currently at scoreboard:
Visuals 6.5/10
Gameplay 7.5/10 - (affected mostly by what I discussed above about there being nothing to do during certain parts)
Depth and Scope: 8.5/10
replayability: 8/10

Overall (currently): 8/10

Verdict:
Do you like tycoon games? do you like money? do you like video games and challenges and management?!
Then why are you not supporting this?!
If you like all of those things
