reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's been a while since I wanted to try a good Game development simulator. After reading the reviews and watching let's plays of Game Dev tycoon and Game Dev Story, I came to the conclusion that they both were lacking of deep gameplay and customization mechanics. On the contrary it seemed to be one of the strenght of Mad Games Tycoon which is exactly what convinced me to give it a try.

...and I do not regret it so far:  this game is already very good even on EA. There are flaws and annoying issues of course but also great gameplay mechanics and very good ideas in this game.

Pro's:

-Dozens of game genres (Rpg, RTS, FPS, TPS, Sim, MMO, Arcade, Sport, Fantasy, Strategy....) which can be mixed together with a subgenre AND one of the hundred of themes (SuperHeroes, WW2, Pirates, Mafia, Space, Wizards, Planes, Tanks...). This system allows you to make very unique and customized games following (or not) the public current expectations.
-Office configuration: You create the rooms where your developpers will work, allowing more space and more workforce to key sectors (Research, Development, Support, Server Rooms, Marketing...) This system reminds very much of Theme Hospital and Prison Architect.
-Characters levelling: Your developpers gain experience in different skills when making games or following courses on specific aspects. You can train a Sound and music effect" expert team working specifically on music-based game for example
date:
the possibilities are huge.
-Ability to create your own game engines: Another gameplay approach is the engine development. Bad at game development? You can create games dedicated engines (customizable with a lot of functionnalities) and sell them to the competitors that will send you royalties when they make games with your engines. This alternate gameplay is one of the examples of the game's depth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

30 hours in, early access review.

Thumbs down because it's in Early Access, it needs a lot of balancing, and some of the current implementation seems baked in that I don't like. However...

The game gives good process, in a Civilization-like manner. You have a couple desks, you release a game, make money, buy more desks, add more rooms, sell more copies, buy a bigger place etc etc etc. This part is very addictive since there really is a ton of stuff (9 different desks, 20-some different rooms, 100+ game subjects etc) to build and set up. However...

Balance: Easy is a walk in the park, while Normal suddenly becomes practically impossible to make money, unless you just concentrate on making game engines and doing contract work. I can't imagine this being what the develoers had in mind. You can release a game that gets good reviews, and release a game with the same staff and setup 6 months later and get Worst Game Of The Year award.

Design decisions: You start in a garage with not much space, but enough for a small dev space, research center, toilet, and perhaps a marketing office. All this needs to be outfitted a la The Sims. Desks over there, plants over here, lighting, heating, ceiling fans, first aid kid, and on and on. Quite fun in fact. But then you make enough money to move to a bigger place. The game sells all your stuff and plops you down in an empty room where you have to do the whole thing over again. This is less fun. And there are TWELVE different building sizes, and each time you have to put the rooms, desks, plants, lights... This appears baked into the design. It would be so much better to add onto existing space, so you could have fun designing the more exotic rooms you didn't have access to before, because you didn't have the space.

There are other balance issues, like getting access to console research when you barely have enough money to buy toilet paper, the bank's suicidal-like willingness to continue to loan you ever increasing amounts of money, despite never having made a successful game (Normal difficulty), but this is EA, so we'll see.

Steam forums are dead, but perhaps discussion of this game takes place on another forum.

Which raises the question: How do you make a 'deep' game with this subject matter? As a gamer, you have foreknowledge of the history of games. Adventure games were really big for a while, but now they're not. The Dreamcast flopped. The PS is gonna be big. If you know all that, the game should be easy. If you don't know that (or set the game to random trends) then the winning and losing will appear arbitrary.

I'll be back for 1.0.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun game developing game in which you are not just making video games but are actually runing a full fledged game development studio.
In that effect it's gameplay is more of the mix beetween games like hospital or rolecoaster tycoon and recent Game Development tycoon and Gamer's go.

Micromanagment might seem a bit putting off in the begining but it will soon be barely noticable.

You are also no longer weighted down by being able to develop only one game at the time. You can have multiple teams working on different projects.

Aside from Micromanaging and some complaigns in regards to balancing and graphics looking like Sims, I have realy had not seen anyone bring up any other issues. And depending on how you feel about them, you might not even have problems with this things.

Game is far enough in the Beta that it's playable without any major problems thought some might still occur based on how unlucky you might get. But dev's seem to be nice and are genually trying to fix what they can.

Would I advise this game anyone looking for Game designer tycoon? Obviously yes, but do be prepared to be a bit more involved with your studio this time around.

Like most people looking to buy this game, I came in hoping for a version of Game Dev Tycoon with an expanded feature set. While that is true, this game is severely lacks polish. There seems to be little rhyme or reason as to why games succeed or do not. Though I did not play for long, a basic explanation of the mechanics would go a long way to increasing my enjoyment. This game also sorely lacks professional localization. Sometimes translation errors are funny, but when your command of english is so bad that your tutorial only half-communicates the message it's time to bring in a native speaker of the language. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This may be early access material, but it feels like very early access. More troubling is the fact that the developer suffers from a complete lack of focus on so many areas of the game (as others have mentioned).

Here's an example:
I get that toilets is a part of every day life, but when your little worker ants go potty as the game speeds forward at a pace where weeks are seconds, I see no reason why I should be treated to the view said ants taking a 15 second potty break, and then don't even wash their hands. That's right. After 15 weeks spent on a potty break (don't ask me what they ate), don't even wash their hands. Filthy animals!

I'm not saying I want the developer to add a new animation just to show me that my employees are wasting another couple of weeks washing their hands, I'm saying we're getting distracted by this whole potty nonsense to begin with! Just like the developer! There's no reason to even show such behavior at all, unless we're moving at a real time pace, in which case, those filty animals better wash up! A simple complaint notification about there not being a proper bathroom with a toilet and sink would be more than enough.

In Game Dev Tycoon, the employees need vacations now and again. That's fine. Perfect, in fact... because this isn't a real time kinda game. Focus on the big stuff, and not the potty. Please.

Another example of the developer wasting time:
There's no need for 3D models just to make a thumbnail representation of each individual worker ant. The 3D models currently in use are so badly made, I can't even tell race or gender most the time. I was playing the game, and it suddenly struck me that I only looked at the stats when hiring people. Go figure! My brain told me to hire the most skilled worker ants over the rest. I forgot all about being politically correct" and trying to "diversify" my staff

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I really wish I could select something in between thumbs up and thumbs down here. I love management / business sim games and this one has some really good innovations. The developers did a good job trying to display all aspects of the gaming industry into this game, from the simple stand-alone game productions up to MMOs which you can host on your own servers.

What breaks the game, is the balancing. The game is way too easy and is getting repetitive quite soon, despite all the different rooms and options. After you have survived the initial period you need to research the first available techs by doint contract work and developing crappy engines which you sell ridiculously overprized without a problem, you are done. Every following game will be a hit with 90% + ratings. It's hard to impossible to go broke then and the remaining 80% of game time is just doing the same over and over again.

+ a must for business sim fans
+ nice innovations and ideas in the game
+ good presentation for a business sim

- way too easy
- gets boring quickly

3/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access game, but the issues listed below should have been taken care of pre-early-access-release.

- Tool tips are missing in a majority of places,
- English is quite obviously NOT the primary language of the developers,
- Staff needs are not apparent until they become an issue,
- Creating a game is not intuitive (beyond the most very basic game).

These items need to be tweaked:

- Staff pathing is horrific,
- Not being able to hire a staffer until he gets a pop machine?  Dumb.,
- Room sizes are a bit out of proportion (bathrooms must be built quite a bit bigger than a single stall would require),
- Understanding WHAT all the sliders are, and why, when developing games is a head-scratcher,
- When an item is locked for some reason it would be nice to know what you need to do to unlock it (more tool tips...)

The game isn't totally broken, and I'm hoping in a few months it's actually more playable.  My bet is that the reviews listed in Steam are mostly the developers faking the game's reviews so people buy it.  Shame on them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played this game around an hour but that's long enough I reckon to give me the feeling that I don't care for it overly much. I'm not saying it's bad, but I couldn't get straight into it like I did Game Dev Tycoon, which I think is better. There's just something about it - it seems to be missing something, soul, atmosphere, appropriate sound effects and game feedback. I don't feel immersed and I don't care about my character. Everything happens so damn fast, too.

There are other issues, like lack of a tutorial or help, so you have to figure it out for yourself. Personally I also find many of the sound effects annoying (and the music) so I turn them down (many sound like something out of the early 90s). I don't much care for the UI either - too much clicking and mousing around for buttons. Another thing that annoys me is that my character is always followed/surrounded by icons and other info graphics, especially when he is at the desk working. It seems cluttered and looks ugly.

On the plus side, the graphics are otherwise generally nice and the devs seems to have put quite a lot of thought into the game dev world elements (but it doesn't work as well as Game Dev Tycoon). And to their credit the devs seem to be very active in developing and updating the game.

But I just can't get excited about it, it leaves me cold, and somewhat irritated. If they halved the price, I might say it was worth a buy, but at present, I regret my purchase decision.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have played both Mad Games Tyccon and Game Dev Tycoon.. both are pretty similar. I first played Game Dev Tycoon and loved it, so then I got Mad Games Tycoon.... here are some irritating gameplay aspects.... poor controls. You have to arrow key around the map of your building, no mouse control watsoever. No tutorial. Nonexistent. Poor design on how to build various rooms. Poor gameplay in general.... you work to level up your employees, go to the develop a game and still are only limited by 100% with four  slider bars broken down into four categories, gameplay technology sound and controls. You try to balance them all max is 25% for each category, You would think you would be able to allocate more points towards a specific category once your staff levels up, but no, the best you can do is 40 points and sacrifice something in one of the other categories.  You try your best to get a good score on a game , spend lots of money researching , leveling staff and it really doesnt seem to pay off since this game seems to consistently give out bad reviews, much like game dev tycoon, where they'll tell u suck, but not really the reasons why. ... I was interested in this game because it looked alot like sims of the past, like sim theme hospital... but alas, it is not.... i really wish someone would make a fun sim on here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have one comprehensive criticism with this game. I don't think this will change, at all, although it's just in pre-alpha. And, that is, that they have this pop-up boxes PLUS they animate the entire screen once the pop up boxes are clicked off.

Why is this a problem? It is an epilepsy hazzard. Even though, I don't think I have it, I am very sensitive to screens flashing all over the place.

For instance, WoW had an animation whereupon if you were in a vehicle and you were taking damage, they made a red vignette flash around the screen. When I contacted Blizzard about it, they had already provided to completely remove it.

I understand that the pop-ups are there to create interest in the game, but literally, they could provide a side icon that is permanent, that could light up when whatever state is ready, lights it up.

I notice that if something small is on the screen, permanently there, and if it simply lights up, it doesn't cause so much eye stress.

Secondly, losing control of the game is terribly annoying to me. And, this is the 2nd complaint about these pop-ups.

Let's think about this for a second. If I am the executive director of a company, no one is going to send me a pop-up to tell me they are done with their poster marketing campaign. In fact, I find it highly juvenile that you don't have a queue of tasks for all departments.

Also, you have no feedback, nor projections of what tasks are hoped to accomplish by their monetary expenditure.

You've flushed out the other Game Tycoon games, but have left out the key components of why the successsful tycoons were so successful, feedback.

You can't have a game with the detail of self production and self publication and leave out any feedback of what you're going to get from spending any money or contracts, or campaigns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't played this game for long as you can see. But does not mean i can't make a review about it... So when i entered this game, I was kinda really hoping I would see something similar to game dev tycoon... But this game is different big time... Not in a good way...
First off

The graphics they used aren't really that good for what type of game this is suppose to be. it kinda feels like when you compare Game of War to Clash of Clans graphics wise... In this case, Mad games Tycoon to Game Dev Tycoon. The graphics for this game are just mad.. (see what i did there).

This game requires to much to learn how to properly play it, and takes to long to do 1 task. Like making a game engine has never been more annoying in this. In Game Dev, it was rather simple, you clikc a few buttons, add a few features without going through a giant maze, you name it. Your done.. In this though, You need to click so many things just to add a feature. it is annoying, and just rude to make a player do that. Games like this are for casual players... They failed on that part.

overall, I disliked my first 20 minutes of playing this. I spent more time writing this review then palying it so far. So in this, They should of made this a casual type game. They failed to make you start off in a lowly garage". They failed to make reasonable graphics for this type of game... the plus side is though.. this is still in Early Access.. So they can fix it whenever they want...

i would say.. Don't be afraid to make something completely similar to game Dev.. Your idea your going towards is perfect. How much customization you can put into your office space
date: How you can completely choose what your staff members will be. just really good mechanics in some cases.. but just a lot of things screwed up that are quite important.\n\n(Also about the fact that you have to wait a second for every pop up to fade in is quite annoying)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't really recommend a game that's unplayable. How is it unplayable? Well, the game's purpose is the simulate a game development studio. The main mechanic of the game is the allotment of resources to the different aspects of a game. Should you focus more on game depth or beginner friendliness? What percentage of the budget should you devote to graphics vs. sound? etc. Apparently, the game favors particular combinations of the sliders which represent these values. Thus, to create a successful game, you need to randomly guess what would make a game of that genre and of that topic successful. Good luck with that, as after an hour of trial and error I have yet to come up with anything. There isn't even a good wiki or forum to reference (although I am a big believer that a game should never require you to utilize outside resources in order for you to play it). I honestly don't know how there are any positive reviews, as I don't know how anyone could figure out how to do well in this game.

Of course, I could be completely wrong about all of this, as there is no tutorial yet. So for all I know, I may have completely misinterpreted everything. I might try this game again after I watch some Let's Plays and they release a tutorial.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have seen alot of games in my life, from Rollercoaster Tycoon to Call of Duty and Fifa to The Sims. I can enjoy all sorts of games, so i am open for new things, and this one got me hooked for now xD so why not give my opinion on what seems to be a promesing game.

Brings back memories, when i start playing and find myself still playing 4-5 hrs later.
For me its the best 15€ i spend this year (i know, 2015 just started, but worth mentioning imo) and to be honest, i didnt expected that!
It looked like an ok game to me, but its way better then i imagined.
If you like tycoon games, are willing to put some hours into the game to get to learn it, and are a game-fan just like me, i would not hesitate and spend those 15€ on this game.

Remember its early acces, it needs more fine-tuning, but no game-breaking problems encountered yet! (Seen ohter Early-Acces games doing much MUCH worse!)
Developer is active on Steam forum, listening to their customers, something i can only praise!
Game gets regular updates, adding content, so they are working on it! (i was very pleased to see an even larger company building after a certain update this week, no such thing as to much space :)

All those who complaign its the same as game dev tycoon:
1) du-uh, they are both game dev tycoon games, and from what i hear (dont have game dev) there are plenty of differences....
2)The more choices we have, the better! Healty competition is good for us, cusomers :)

I really recommend this game to every game-fan!

Thanks Eggcode for making this game, and keep up the good work and im sure this will become (already is) a game that will steal alot of free time hours!


+Gameplay
I like the Sims Style - build and decorate - ur company (More objects are always welcome)
+Graphics are not SUPER but deff ok
+Start small - Grow big
+Deff worth its money


-Sounds are getting enoying very quickly :/
-Some important things should be added later (maybe u guys are already working on this)
*A pause / speed up button. (while still being able to give commands PLZ :) )
*Being able to adjust room sizes by dragging the walls? its a pain to have to sell the whole room and everything in it (and loosing alot of money in the process) because it should be 1 square larger to fit in what u want to fit in
*Pauze development / research / ....
*Simple tutorial!
Learhing curves can be steep at the beginning! so why not start a tutorial in the smallest garage building, where u show ppl how to get set up right?...
*More in-depth info on all sorts of stuff
*More ways to spend ur money mid-late game
*Why can other developers build their consoles, and not us?
*More content, more objects, more more more xD
